description:
I was not a fan of this bake tart, but I think that's really just my personal preference. It tastes kind of strange to me - not really a cheesecake and not really a tart. I think it would have been better if I took it home and froze it before eating. 

I also feel like they are incredible inefficient here (hence the -1 star). They have one long line to order and ring you up. They should really just make space for a second or third register since it takes way too long to get some bake tarts.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
My brother and his girlfriend took a trip downtown for some much needed Pokémon hunting and came home with half a dozen of these instagram worthy baked cheese tarts. Damn, what a sentence.

My brother had no idea what he had in his hand. His explanation, "I saw a line waiting and thought, "let's go for it."" Well, I'm glad he did because these little babies have been popping up all over my Instagram feed for a while now and I rarely ever venture downtown so... 

He opted for 2 of the regular, 2 matcha, and 2 matcha with honey. My family and I split them into equal pieces so everyone was able to try all 3 flavors. 

Regular - super simple, not too sweet. 
Matcha - VERY strong matcha flavor. If you're a lover of matcha then you're a lover of this.
Matcha Honey - This is their limited time one and I have to say, I'm not as impressed as I thought I would be. I love matcha and I love honey, but I felt like the flavors fell flat a bit for this hype.

Overall, it wasn't me who waited in the line so I can't be too bad. Flavors are pretty good, but for the price of one... I'll stick to regular egg tarts.
author: Venus L.

description:
This place often has a crazy long line!  So, one afternoon, we decided to give it a try.  

I feel like they're like a... soft-cheesecake like feeling in a tart shell.  The filling itself is ok -- a little on the plain side.  They have toppings on the side (coco powder, cinnamon powder) that you can add.  I liked it better once I'd topped it with some coco powder.

For my sweet dessert fix / calories, I'd go with Beard Papa.  Personal pref.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Sweet little indulgence in the form of mini cheese tarts.  Creamy and well-balanced in sweetness, the pastries come fresh off the oven at the basement level of Westfield Mall.  The tarts come in two flavors, original cheese and matcha (for those addicted to green tea's bittersweetness).  Aside from eating them warm or at room temperature, they recommend popping them in the freezer for that ice cream like texture.  Line varies in length depending the time of day.  

The custard like texture had me addicted like squirrels on nuts.  Just kept on going till they were gone.  Damn it... Now I'll have to go back and grab another box...  Save yourself the trouble and buy a dozen!
author: Ken L.

description:
The Cheese Tarts here are okay as a nice little treat but they are nothing that special. I definitely wouldn't wait in line to get them. For something that small, it is pretty pricey. The original ones are $3.50 and the limited ones for the day are $3.65 plus tax.

On my most recent visit, I was walking around the mall and there was no wait so me and my friend decided to get some Cheese Tarts. We got the Original, Matcha, and Matcha with Gold Leaf. I was told that the Matcha with Gold Leaf had honey in it, making it a little sweeter than the regular Matcha. Out of the three, the Original was still my favorite. 

I've been here multiple times and have yet to be blown away. The tarts are tasty, but I wouldn't venture out of my way to get them. However, I do think they make for a nice gift. I believe if you order like six or more of them, they give you a nice box to hold them in.
author: Michael L.

description:
I missed a great Monday Night Football game to see the hype of the newest bakery and hottest business in the Westfield Shopping Centre. I heard this bakery have a long line.  But when an NFL game is on, every viewer's eyes on the TV. Therefore most businesses are not too busy and the best time to visit.

The bakery is located in the basement and in the food court area. The bakery specializes in Japanese tarts with the gooey filling. San Francisco is the first American city with the unique bakery. With the success of the first location, more cities are on the way. 

My first visit I had the popular Cheese Tart. For $3.50 + tax, I get a palm-size tart with the gooey cheesecake filling. The treat is cute and tiny that fits the palm of my hand. But taste-wise, I did not find the tiny treat all that stunning. I am not a big fan of small treats for a big price. When I spend big, I expect "Big". 

I was better off with a Cream Puff from Beard Papa or stayed home and watched the football game. 

Assumingly more of the Japanese bakery will expand to other cities. Don't expect me to visit those future locations soon.
author: Matt G.

description:
I guess this simply wasn't what I was expecting. 

It's an interesting concept, but I think the execution leaves a lot of be desired. I did only get a lukewarm tart, so maybe these are better when they're fresh out of the oven. But really I wish that the shell was a little more crispy, like others have described it it's texture is more of a crumbly shortbread cookie, and a little softer than a traditional tart shell. There wasn't much flavor to the shell, it was mostly just sugar and butter. The filling was a little more interesting, almost like a custard + cream cheese mousse. I enjoyed the light fluffy texture, but I think it could have been a little more creamy. Again the favor simply wasn't there. There was only a very light cheese flavor that didn't work as well with the already fatty butter texture and flavor. 

Overall, I'll probably not come back to this store, they were SMALL for the price (at 3.5 that's the same price as the massive egg tarts at Golden Gate Bakery). And there really wasn't anything special about these, maybe they're better in Japan.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Whenever I'm shopping at Westfield, I definitely try to get a Bake Cheese Tart. I've had the one in Hong Kong and they taste exactly the same - not too sure about the price though, but I do find these quite pricy ($3.50 per tart - original flavor). 

The cheese tarts taste the best when you eat them immediately after purchasing! The crust has the perfect amount crisp - it's like a shortbread cookie, but not as sweet. The filling very soft and somewhat liquidy once you reach the middle - kind of like a melted cheesecake lol - sounds kind of gross but tastes amazing! I've had some of their other special flavors as well, such as the strawberry one, but I always find myself preferring the original!

This place does run out of the flavored ones pretty quickly, so I'd recommend getting their early if you're trying to get one of the special flavors! 

Although I do love these cheese tarts, I definitely wouldn't wait more than 10 minutes for these, especially for the flavored ones.
author: Stacey Y.

description:
I cannot get enough of these omg. They are so so delicious, and not one person I've introduced them to has not ended up loving them too!

I've tried the original and the matcha, but I'm still a bigger fan of the original because I don't like the slightly bitter taste of matcha as much. I love the crust when it's fresh, but the cheesecake consistency of the cheese is just too good after you refrigerate it so that's what I usually end up doing.

It is a little pricey at $3.50 (+ tax) per cheese tart, but tbh it's not that much different from other pastries in downtown SF (sadly) so I feel like it's worth it as a treat since it's so good!
author: Alice C.

description:
Located in the bottom floor of Westfield is this small little bakery that makes adorable Japanese cheese tarts. I ordered both the Original and Matcha Japanese cheese tarts - they were both delicious! Both had a smooth and creamy texture. The Original had a very clean milky flavour to it while the flavour of the matcha one was very strong. 

Tip: order both - they're very opposite in the flavours which actually makes them very enjoyable together!
author: Allan L.

description:
The tarts are OK (they're essentially mini cheesecakes with more crust), but for the price and the wait, I personally don't think they're worth it.

I went a few months back, and there were maybe 10-15 people in line ahead of me. It didn't seem so bad at first since they had plenty of tarts already baked and ready for purchase. However, their process for serving customers is *SO* slow.

When you get to the front of the line, they'll ask you how many you want, and once you do, they'll either get a bag out or start assembling a box. If you're ordering multiple, they'll carefully load your tarts in, and once that's done, they'll ask for your approval of the tarts they chose before packing it all up and sealing the box with a sticker.

Hopefully they've improved and sped up the process since then.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I came here one day on a Friday morning, which was nice because there were no lines. I was so excited to try this place out because I had something similar in Japan. I was hoping this place would be comparable but sadly nothing can compare to Japan. The tarts come in two different flavors: green tea and regular cheese. You can also order them warm or cold, except I felt there wasn't much of a difference between the two. I expected the warm to be fresh and...well warm, but it was more like room temperature. I saw the sign where cold can make it taste like "ice cream" but I rather eat it warm.

For the green tea flavor, I could barely taste the green tea. The reg cheese tart is the way to go if I had to choose between the two. The best part is probably the crust. Also, these aren't cheap. Overall, I wasn't super impressed and would honestly eat cheese/egg tarts from 85 degree bakery. At least those are always good and at a cheaper price.
author: Ester S.

description:
If you are craving a smaller treat and you enjoy cheesecake this is your place! It's basically a mini cheese cake with a very good crunchy crust.

I really enjoyed it and like how you can enjoy it many ways: at room temp, in the fridge and in the freezer. Amazingly enough the crust is able to stay really nice and crunchy even if it's been in the fridge.

I've tried the regular flavor and the matcha flavor. My favorite is still the regular. The matcha flavor had a very strong matcha making the tart more bitter than sweet. Still good but regular was better in my opinion. 

They do have seasonal flavors so I'm looking to try those out when they're out! 

Also tip to avoid a longer wait time is to go during the day!

TLDR; delicious mini cheesecake! Would recommend trying regular!
author: Lulu T.

description:
Bake Cheese Tart is located in the bottom food court of Westfield and right by the Bart entrance. We got there around 2pm on a Saturday and there was a line but it moved pretty fast. I love the display of the cheese tarts and the boxes in the back which spelled out Matcha. 

We got 3 of the original and 3 of the matcha which came out to be around $22. As much as we wanted to eat one right there, we were full from lunch and decided to wait. However, when we got home and opened the box, all the cheese was ruined and fell over to the side. I don't believe we moved the box around that much?? Anyways, they were both very tasty! The matcha one was a little bitter compared to the original one. The original one tasted like a cheesecake. 

Overall, they tasted good but a little expensive to come back and keep buying.
author: Kristie L.

description:
So glad I finally got to try it!!

I was lucky to not encounter a long line on Saturday of Labor Day weekend and only had to wait in line for at most 10 min. The staff was friendly and they had one person take your order first while the cashier processed the order. I first shared a regular cheese tart and a matcha cheese tart on the spot, and then I bought an additional 4 regulars home since they later ran out of matcha. 

The cheese tarts can be a bit soft, gooey, and liquidy, freshly baked. I liked both the regular and matcha! The ones I brought home, I ate straight from the box after they had been chilled in the refrigerator. I like both kinds, chilled and liquidy. The cheese is more solidified and chewier if you refrigerate them. I've heard other people recommend chilling the tarts as well. 

These tarts are definitely not cheap - $3.50 for one, and $3.65 for a matcha one. It just goes to show just how ridiculous rent is in SF that they have to up the price for food :( 

I asked the cashier how long their matcha is for and it would run until early October, so y'all still have some time!!
author: Valerie T.

description:
I'm crying because wow. How did we get so lucky as to have these heavenly cheese tarts brought to Westfield mall! I will literally BART to SF Powell Station just to pick some of these up.

We visited for the first time on Thursday evening just before closing and they still tasted fresh! One piece is $3.50, but if you want a box of 6 - it's like $20. Seems expensive, only because I'd love to be able to purchase a box of 10 for $20, but I'm sure they are fairly priced. I wouldn't be able to make these at home the same way, that's for sure. 

I'm also a cheese fan, so this review may not be for the lactose intolerant! There were contrasts of sweetness and savory for taste, and consistency of the cheese filling vs. the crust. I was very impressed and honestly can't wait to come back!
author: Melanie B.

description: I originally saw a video of this place on Facebook and had to make a pit stop to see what the hype is all about. It's located inside the Westfield Centre. The line may look long but it moves pretty quickly. They had the original, matcha, and matcha honey flavors when I went. I ordered a dozen combination of all three flavors. They were similar to cheesecake but lighter and fluffier. Of the three flavors I preferred the original. If you want a more cheesecake texture, place the tart in the fridge. If you want a more ice box cake texture, place the tart in the freezer. The cheese tarts are good as is and best if eaten the same day.
author: Lanha T.

description:
My mom's first reaction in seeing this:

Golden Gate custard tarts?  (In Chinese)

After my eyes slightly widened, I mouthed "cheese cake"! (Again in Chinese)

After a few minutes and ensuing bites, "aaaaahhhh".

This happened recently, approximately four months after I shared a gift box with my parents in April.  At that time, there was no reaction.

The difference?  I bought this after having a business lunch.  The line was six deep, relatively short compared to my friend's stories about his visits.  Located in the back of the basement Westfield Mall food court, this stand is low key.  When I ordered, I noticed the patrons ahead of us mostly walked off with three boxes (six per box), the order limit.

After walking a few steps, since we skipped dessert, we both open a box and pulled a fresh one out to try.  The flavor of the day was not available (nor was there a sign for it) so I tried the original (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=G1aZtgX6PAJRUAswiKc24w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q); it was delicious and addicting.  This was a sharp contrast from the one I tried in April which was a day or two later.  I highly recommend reheating the take home ones at low heat to enjoy the flavors and textures.  My friend bought me a chocolate (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LcKorJymXZZvzp76ID6Y9g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) in April too and that wasn't memorable either.  

If you are a cheesecake fan, you will enjoy this but make sure to have it fresh to optimize your enjoyment.  No wonder my mom said Golden Gate!
author: Mike C.

description:
Do you like egg tarts? Try the bake cheese tart!

Ordered: 
- 6 in a box for $20.08 (tax not included)

Tina's Travels and Tabloid 
- Oh my goodness, melts in your mouth. I would drive to the city just to get these. But also, I would drive anywhere for food.
- These are a bit pricey, but good for it! 
- Let me tell you, 6 wouldn't have made it to the car if I wasn't on a lightweight diet. Just saying!
author: Tina N.

description:
Mmm cheese tarts! Glad I finally got to try this place out. My BF & I had tickets to Candytopia so we decided to stop by before we went. Its located next to Ghiradelli at the food court. There was no line at all when we went as well, so it's best to come on a weekday if you want to check it out. 

We went for 6 of the Matcha and original cheese tart. It was 6 for $22 which is very pricey IMHO. I really liked the plain cheesetart way more than the matcha. I think the Matcha was too overpowering.. the plain cheesetart tho is delicious.. light, buttery, and just the right amount of salty. 

Why am I giving 3 stars? Well, because they're good but overpriced and they're not something I would drive all the way to DT SF for. :)
author: Alyssa C.

description:
TLDR: pretty good cheese tarts but on the pricey side and kinda sad, off putting service 

Cheese tart: I tried both the original and the matcha one and they are both super yummy. I personally like the original one more as it has the perfect balance of sweet, salty, and crunchiness. The matcha is also really good but it's a bit on the bitter side and not my cup of tea.

Price: def on the pricy side and the matcha ones are slightly more expensive than the original. Paid $23.27 for 3 original & 3 matcha 

Service: the workers there seem kinda sad and honestly done with everything LOL it made it feel a bit unwelcoming after waiting in line for a while
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Beautiful and delicious cheese tart.

I really love these tart but one problem I had is the fact that the crust is so hard, otherwise it would have been perfect. 

The moment you take a bite out of it, the crust sucks but the cheese melts in your mouth. Fills your mouth with either original cheese or matcha filling. I really like the matcha one but my friends like the original. Regardless they are delicious but expensive :(

$3.5-3.65 for 1 cheese tart.... I can get 3-4 egg tarts almost as good if not better in Chinatown. I would say this place is a one time thing if you on poverty life.
author: Christopher G.

description:
The first time I saw many food bloggers hyping this place up on Instagram, I thought "is it really that good?" But I still went and tried them anyways.

First time around, I went when it was fairly new, and they only had the classic baked cheese tarts. I got half a dozen. My oh My, I loved them! it's like biting into a pie, but inside it was filled with fluffy sweet cheese goodness. Best believe I ate all 6. They stand at $3.50 each for original flavor, $3.75 for matcha. Definitely on the pricier side. and I thought I was being ripped off at 85 degrees for their $2.50 Hokkaido cheese tarts. yeesh. 

I went back for a second time to try out the matcha cheese tarts, and unfortunately, these weren't that great. The taste of matcha just overpowers the whole tart. it tastes like you bit into a fluff of strong, bitter, matcha. It wasn't sweet at all. I wouldn't recommend this one. So would I come back again? ehh yeah if there wasn't a line. Would I ever wait 30 minutes for them and take a dent to my wallet? Absolutely not.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Believe me when I say that Bake Cheese Tarts are NOTHING like the cheese tarts that you've tried. If you're like me and you were wondering what the hype was all about and why people were waiting line for 20 minutes for cheese tarts (??) then trust me when I say that these cheese tarts are well worth the hype and then some.

Bake Cheese Tart originates from Japan and it has finally crossed the Pacific Ocean to land right in the Westfield mall food court of SF's Union Square, and I could not be happier. 

The crust of the tart is so buttery and rich but not too hard and not too soft, and the cheese filling is a whipped texture that is not too sweet. Each bite into this cheese tart is a flavor explosion that is sure to leave you feeling like you've just the best thing you've ever tried.

I also tried the strawberry cheese tart which I like even more than the original because the strawberry adds just an extra bit of sweetness and a bit of tartness to the cheese tart that is also so impactful.

For a limited time, Bake Cheese Tart has released matcha cheese tarts which I've been dying to get my hands on and am planning to make a trip very soon. Bake Cheese Tart is an absolute must for me whenever I'm in Union Square - my trip up there is not complete without it!
author: Pooja M.

description:
I saw this shop a couple years ago on a trip in Shanghai and remember the long line outside this shop. Fast forward to today in Westfield, SF - we finally get to try these delicious tarts in the bay! 

Don't get confused between a cheese tart and a dan tat. They look the same, but completely different. The hype is real. Thankfully, I didn't have to wait in a ridiculously long line when I came.

Imagine a molten lava cheesecake. Sounds like heaven right? Becuase it is. Their tart is soft and has a buttery crunch (not flakey like a dan tats). The inside is fluffy, smooth and has the right amount of sweetness (with the help of the cheese cutting into the sweetness). 

They usually have 2 flavors: the original and another rotation flavor. I've seen chocolate and strawberry. They are offering their matcha flavor soon and I cannot wait! I hope they keep it as a permanent flavor because matcha is everything! 

The only down fall? Their price. It's almost $4 for a tart. You can buy 2-3 dan tats with that.
author: Samantha F.

description:
Oh my goodness. It is pure goodness in a small little tart.
I know it's hyped up but gotdamnit, it is good.
First of all, if you go during long lines then you'll get hangry and it might affect the way the cheese tart taste because of the anger.
Second of all, I love cheese so of course I'm biased.
Third, this s*** is pretty expensive. It's 3-3.5$...trying to rob me but I like it so much that they can take my money. Just give me moreeee.

If you are from around the area then you can definitely avoid the long lines by going during opening hours, or mid day like around 2-3:30pm. I haven't gone the weekend yet and I don't even wanna know. If I have to wait in a long line then I'll pass.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
Whooo what a treat!

I usually don't like to visit places that are known to have shops in Japan because people buy into the "omg it's from Japan and it's so good" hype but I caved after seeing all the social media's posts made about this tart! And wow is it good! :) 

On a random weekday afternoon, I decided to pay them a visit. There wasn't much of line because the strawberry flavored tarts sold out (they do restock which took about 10-15 minutes from my experience). NOTE: they will only sell you things on display so you can't preorder the flavors and wait. With that being said, the moment they did restock, a long line formed. 

I purchased 12 cheese tarts (6 originals/6 strawberries). They run about $3.50 each (~ $20 for a box of 6). 

If you had to choose between their seasonal flavor or the original, I'd choose the seasonal one since they're only available for a limited time and they're usually really good. I shared my order with coworkers, friends, and family and they all burned through the seasonal ones really fast! 

The flavor and texture of the tart was solid. It wasn't overpoweringly sweet and did not taste artificial. The tart was thick and the crust had a good consistent texture and complimented the tart really well. 

Bonus: These tarts taste good cold! A lot of my friends told me to freeze them. I gave it a try and wow it sort of taste like ice cream! 

Overall, great treat to treat yourself or others during special occasions. Everyone I know gives this place a stamp of approval! Will be back next month for Matcha cheese tarts!
author: Ida H.

description:
Nestled in the food court in Westfield mall, Bake Cheese Tart offers something I haven't seen in the states yet: baked cheese tarts and matcha tarts. 

Cheese tarts are similar to Chinese egg tarts, just with more of a cheese rather than custard taste to them. One of the problems with traveling is that you taste foods at their pinnacle, and unfortunately the cheese tarts I've tasted elsewhere were leagues above these. These weren't bad by any means, just nothing spectacular. The crust is crisp and it's creamy, but just missing some cheesy flare and buttery goodness. The price is definitely on the expensive side @ ~$3.50 for one or ~$20 for 6. 

Something to note is they have a little condiment section far off to the left of the register (I completely missed it when I went). 

It's a novel dessert and you may want to try it if you're wanting to try something new but I don't think I will be back.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Totally not worth the wait and the money. 
The cheese tarts taste too sweet and too salty altogether, the texture is too runny.
Definitely not coming back!
author: Irene X.

description:
So I've seen the videos and heard all the hype and finally got down there on a Saturday afternoon to try these. It's in the bottom level food court of Westfield mall by Cako and Sur La Table and the Powell bart entrance. I waited in line for about 10 minutes, but I didn't mind because I've heard of longer waits on a weekend (I guess the hype died down a bit).  

So for $3.50/ tart....It was good and I would eat it again, but I wouldn't make it a habit at that price per tart. It seems like it would be a good thing to bring to a party but at around $20 for 6, definitely not worth it for me. My crust was super hard (a little overcooked), so I wasn't a fan of that, but the insides were gooey, delicious, not too cheesy, not overly sweet or salty. Basically, a perfect balance. They weren't selling any speciality flavors such as matcha when I went, but I would be interested in trying another flavor!
author: April L.

description: Okay so maybe if I had to wait in line for these tarts like some other reviewers, they wouldn't be that good. NO THAT'S A LIE THEY'RE SO GOOD!!! Honestly, they're creamy and rich but not too heavy and the crust is flaky and I love the optional additions of cinnamon, chocolate, and caramel. Seriously, these are good and the different levels of the box makes me feel like my tarts live in an apartment building! Can't wait to try the matcha tarts!
author: Marissa F.

description: New flavor.   Matcha and matcha with black honey ( 3.65).  I love their cookie crust.  No lines on sunday since everyone was busy with blue angels.
author: Helen L.

description:
I first discovered these tarts cause of a friend of a friend, they look pretty simple and plain but they're amazing little perfect bites, with perfect oomph of sweet/savoury/I don't know why they're so addictive. Not overly cheesy or sickenly sweet, they're perfect alone or with a mild tea.

Then they started popping up on IG, and I found out they released a MATCHA version. Yaaaass. It has slightly less dairy oomph than the original but still really good. Could do with a bit more matcha flavor, maybe a matcha powder dusting?

Went late afternoon on weekend and there wasn't a long line, it moved incredibly quickly. It was kinda pricey, six little tartlets goes for about $20. 

For some reason some of their tarts get overly bruleed/brown, and I've noticed they try to pick those when you're not looking...lol I don't mind too much but thought that was...strange.
author: Ethel C.

description:
I thought Bake might have been just another fad that had been hyped up by people on the internet. However they lived up to the hype with both their original cheese tart and matcha cheese tart. 

Both have really great flavors but I know that the matcha isn't for every one. It seems like more people prefer the original flavor because the matcha flavor is very strong.

The store inside a mall and is at the basement level. Very easy access with the BART. There is plenty of seats for you to sit, relax, and eat. 

Keep in mind that you are only allowed to purchase 6 at a time. The original is $3.50 each and the matcha $3.65 each.
author: Yvonne H.

description:
I've been excited to try BAKE CHEESE TART ever since we got a flyer about it hanging on our apartment door months ago for their grand opening. 

The idea of having to wait in a long ass line deferred me until recently. It only took us 10 minutes to get our tarts on a Saturday afternoon! 

$3.50 each, so they are pricey. I thought the tarts were just OK at room temperature (when you purchase them). Once I took them home, that's where all the real magic happens. Chill it in the fridge for something similar to a cheesecake, or bake it in the oven to enjoy the warm crust and melty cheese. I'm a fan of both the original and seasonal strawberry. 

Sweet (but not too sweet), savory, warm, cold, etc. - it's a universal dessert for everyone!
author: Laverne N.

description: I've heard great things about these tarts and didn't want to wait in a long line when it first opened. However I went recently and I still had it wait in line. The line moved pretty slowly considering the limited selection of tarts on the menu. I tried the original and the matcha. Although the matcha flavor was very strong, I preferred the original. It tasted very similar to a cheesecake.
author: Kelly C.

description: I tried the green tea tart and think the cheese tart is the way to go if anyone is deciding between the two.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Well you gotta love cheese cake or a nice sugar/shortbread like cookie.....filling is a light/fluffy cream cheese base (options of strawberry and chocolate) in a sweet, cookie tart shell. 

Took a quick BART ride from the East Bay to SF ($8 round trip) with some co-workers and fortunately, no line! YAY....just the presentation and openness of the kiosk in the food court definitely makes you want to get a bunch....even their packaging is really colorful and eye-catching...but sadly that's about it for me. 

Did it WOW me or any of my co-workers? not really and probably enjoyed the tart shell more (not a good thing) than the filling...was it good? Sure! Am I craving more...meh!

Glad we tried and may try again down the road....not rushing since its about $3.50 for a small tart. Also, I prefer another Japanese dessert ('light, creamy, flaky and delicious') at the other kiosk close by! :) Now that is some major sweet noms!
author: Cheryl M.

description:
I drove all the way to the city from Walnut Creek just to pick up a dozen of these! So worth the drive!!
Fluffy cheese cake and crunchy crust on the outer edges, but a little softer in the middle. Sweetness was just the right amount. I don't think I can eat regular cheese cake now. Friday at noon, there were only 3 people in line.
author: Angela A.

description:
This is mostly based on the sheer amount of happiness I felt when the first bite melted into my mouth and slid happily into my tummy. 

Honestly, I only first noticed this place earlier in the week when I stopped at Westfield to grab a quick bite before the Ed Sheeran concert!!!!! It was hard not to notice the long ass line that wrapped around the corner. {Tuesday evening, around 5:30pm}

Fast forward a couple of days. Met my sister for lunch at 11:30AM on a Thursday. There were only four people in line and she was in it. 

The staff was quick and friendly. We tried both the regular cheese tart and the matcha. Holy goodness. I closed my eyes and enjoyed it. It was creamy and sweet, and the crust was just right.
author: Lani S.

description:
I did it! You know I had to do it, y 'all! I was peepin' them for a while now. Morning times on the weekdays- forget it! Afternoons (lunchtime), heck NO! But the evenings, like from (6PM-Close), Yup! The lines are shorter, the staff is calm and chill but unfortunately, my cheese tart was not warm-blah! That sure didn't stop me from eating one....

From the raving review's, I couldn't help but want to try one. Though honestly, I was waiting for the hype to go down. BAKE is well known in Hong Kong and Singapore! They offer various different flavors depending on the season: Honey Lemon, Chocolate, Original Cheese, and many more!  

So, how was my first experience trying a Cheese Tart? Well, it was DELICIOUS! The first bite is heaven I tell ya! Buttery and firm but cracks upon sinking your teeth into it!! The filling melts in your mouth, like a fondant, and the crust is crisp and firm, slightly crumbly and best eaten when consumed right on the spot or warmed up slightly in the oven! (Warning: Do Not Microwave). The inside of the cheese tart had been creamy, luscious and surprisingly not too overwhelming like I assumed. I could have easily eaten two of the cheese tarts in one seating. 
This place is worth a try, but not something to go out of your way to get! Also, the hefty price of $3.50, Whoo! This place would break my pockets if I became addicted! 

**I hear there will be more flavors coming soon! I remember seeing a similar place in Hong Kong and Singapore and they had Chocolate Tarts! I wouldn't be surprised if they begin making a Chocolate Tart! HAHA! We'll just have to see it to believe it!**
 
Enjoy!
author: Porsche C.

description:
What's the hype about? This place was always popping when it first opened with lines that wrapped so long that you would have thought they were giving away free tarts. 

It was filling up Instagram feeds and there was quite a buzz. During lunch I saw that the line wasn't too bad so I had to try it. Yes, it is expensive at $3.50. Yes, if you take it home it's not as good. Yes, you should eat it hot. However, I really enjoyed it. The crust was flakey and had a nice subtle sweetness to it. The cheese tart itself was melt in your mouth delicious and really not like anything else I have tried. 

Would I go back? Yes! Easy. Now I'm not a baller by any means, but honestly most desserts cost me $3-5/piece easy. So for a cool $3.50 I get a really tasty treat flown in Japan. Hey I just saved myself a plane ticket!
author: Melissa N.

description:
With a buttery crust and a deliciously light a fluffy cheese mousse, these little tarts exist to please!

Bake Cheese Tart has always had a long line whenever I would pass by so when my friends and I noticed that the line wasn't absurdly long last Friday night, we just had to try some of these cheese tarts! Their box size is meant to fit a half dozen, so I just had to buy six so that it looks all pretty and fancy schmany in its little paper six-room dollhouse. Besides the cheese tarts, they also sell Brazillian coffee here which initially seemed out of place, but in retrospect, coffee would have complemented these tarts just perfectly.

So I brought my half-dozen of cheese tarts on a BART ride home and didn't get to try them until ~2hrs later so they weren't necessarily hot and fresh by that time. I was also going into this experience expecting a level of disappointment due to some previous experiences of overhyped Japanese franchises appearing in the states. As a result, I was quite surprised when I took my first bite into the tart because it's pretty good. Given that they're quite small, I don't know if it was $3.50 good, but it was pretty good. I particularly enjoyed the crust which heavily reminded me of a butter cookie place in Japan's Tokyo Station that lots of people I know loved.

If I'm ever in the Westfield area and am craving for a light snack with a cup of coffee, I would definitely stop by Bake Cheese Tart if the queue is not long. More commonly, I can find myself coming by to buy a half-dozen box as a gift for others since the packaging and presentation is absolutely wonderful!
author: Joshua M.

description:
I'm obsesssssssed with these tarts! I'm a fan of the Japanese style cheesecakes so I knew I would love this one. I kinda  found it by accident when looking for something to eat. It was near the end of the day when my husband and I noticed the long line and wondered what it was. After we finished eating, we came back and they were sold out!

So of course, I checked online to see what all the fuss was about and went back the next day! And I'm sooooo glad we did! I love them! I had them fresh from the oven with a hot cup of coffee =) the tarts are perfectly cooked! Perfectly golden brown, soft and crispy crust with a creamy and fluffy filling! YUM!! 

They're insanely expensive but I probably won't be in SF for a while (or anyone in Asia) so it was worth a buy for me. I even brought some home to Toronto and everyone loved it too!
author: Bernadette B.

description:
I tried the original flavor only. They were out of matcha for the day.

The tart shell was the best part of the pastry. They don't just use a generic puff pastry - they create a thin shell that's perfectly crispy and sweet. However, it's downhill from there. The custard smelled like milk that was going bad (it was not curdled or anything), tasted like a milky cream cheese, and was foamy/super runny in texture. Bizarre. Usually the tarts I've had at other restaurants/bakeries have a little more structure in the custard, since it's baked. I did eat it right on the spot, so this was not due to melting/shaking a box around.
author: Nelya T.

description:
I love cheese and bread. Cheese and bread doesnt love me. Coming from a lactose intolerant, gluten sensitive gal, these Bake cheese tarts are the makers and designers of a ooey gooey dream come true. Yes, it's worth the wait. The original freshly baked cheese tart (hailing from japan) is delicious and will melt away any stress you have for the day on the first bite. 

Perfectly gooey, perfect combo of tartness mixed with the savory aftertaste of cheese, these are heaven. I have to mention that if you're anticipating something that is reminicesnt of an eggtart, these aren't it. It is somewhat similar to a portugese egg tart (with the nice glazed burnt top) but instead of egg this is a whole lotta cheese.

I got to try both the original and the matcha--personally, I found the original more to my liking. The Bf enjoyed the matcha as he is not a fan of the tart/sour/sweet combo.

I do have  to mention that the line can get quite long and the prices per tart is not cheap. I believe it's currently $3.50 for an original tart and $3.75 for a special flavor---6 for 20. So if you're planning to splurg, you might as well go all out for these babies.
author: Diane T.

description: I tried a lot of these cheese tarts (of different brands) when I went to Asia.  I had a matcha red bean kind, a blueberry cheese kind, even a durian kind!  Tonight I'm trying a honey matcha kind.  As much as it's good, it's just way overpriced at $4 a piece.  Try once if you're curious, but after that use your money to get actual desserts.
author: Kev H.

description:
YUM! The line seemed a little long but I asked the first person how long they waited and they said 10 mins. 

First time having this and I had no expectations. The signage on this place is terrible too as there really is none, just look for the line of people. 

Right now they have the matcha flavor tarts. Those were good if you like matcha but the originals were delicious. I guess I was expecting a chinese egg tart but it's more like a mini fluffy cheese cake. I love that you get so much more crust on this because that's my favorite part of a cheese cake. 

I totally recommend this if you're in the area. They are so good! 

Also, remember they sell out too, so don't try to roll up here 30 mins before closing hoping to beat the line but finding out there is no line because they are sold out. #truestory
author: Lindsay C.

description:
The first time we tried Bake Cheese Tart was in Kyoto during our honeymoon.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that the ones at Westfield were just as I had remembered.

We just so happened to be passing the Westfield on a Sunday morning around 11am and I wanted to check out Bake to see if there was a long line.  There were only a few people in line, and I was so excited to see that they had matcha cheese tarts!  We ordered a couple of the plain ones and 4 matcha.  

We loved the strong flavor of the matcha cheese tarts, but as some other reviewers mentioned, you can definitely taste the bitterness of the matcha.  

The consistency of the tarts is super smooth and creamy, with a soft/nearly liquid center. The tart shells have a similar flavor to shortbread cookies, and are crisp and sweet.  Even after storing our leftovers in our fridge for a couple of days, the tart shell did not get soggy.  Will definitely be returning!
author: Michelle M.

description:
I was so excited to finally hear that a Japanese cheese tart chain was opening in the Bay! And of course, I had to jump on the bandwagon to see what this hype was about! 

After a long day of shopping, my friend and I stopped by Bake Cheese Tart on a Saturday afternoon and the line was wrapped around the corner of the store. Even though the line seemed long, it went by pretty fast and we waited for about 15 minutes. While we were in line, we looked through the large glass windows and watched the workers bake endless trays of cheese tarts in the oven. At this point, we were both drooling and couldn't wait for these cheese tarts to get in our belly. 

I was watching a video about Bake Vheese Tart and found out that the cheese tarts are made in Japan then shipped all around the world. At the stores, they are baked a second time. They offer a chocolate tart (which is often sold out) and strawberry, which is coming soon! There are self-serve toppings customers can add on the tart, including caramel drizzle and more. 

My friend and I each ordered the original cheese tarts. In my opinion, the cheese tart was average, and it wasn't anything too special compared to the authentic Japanese tarts I have tried in Japan in the past. The cheese filling was sweet and had a fluffy, light texture. The tart itself was buttery, similar to a shortbread cookie. The taste and texture were not bad, but the price is a bit steep for $3.50/per tart.    

If a cheesecake and an egg tart had a baby, it'd be this cheese tart! A good thing is that it's conveniently located in the basement of Westfield in the food court, and right by the bart entrance/exit. If you've never had Japanese cheese tarts before, it's definitely worth a try!
author: Michelle F.

description:
What a Yelp failure... this is the same place in Tokyo Station!

Just amazing, authentic Japanese cheese tarts. Perfectly fluffy, nice texture to the crust, not too sweet, perfectly delicious.

All these people complaining about the price or the line... PSH! Have you even been to Japan before?

This is what's amazing about SF. Delicious, genuine food from around the world. 

One of the best dessert spots in the city! Period! So absurdly disappointed in Yelp's 3.5.
author: Aakash G.

description:
One bite into the "hot and new" trend of cheese tart, I thought I masticate a piece of frozen dough.

Coming to SF, I, as an amateur, heard for the first time in my life, "cheese tart". These cheese tarts appeared by rumor as touching-hot and when biting into it, provide a stream of melted cheese into your tongue, almost burning it to the third degree. Well, I like that idea of burning food.

As I sashayed euphorically into the little shop which hung the store's name a bit too far from where the shop is, I got 6 cheese tarts. My first impression was why on Earth are they making tons of cheese tarts when only serving three customers (including me). My gut told me this ain't good. From what I witnessed, the employees had more cheese tart freshly baked from the oven coming out. I thought to myself, maybe they will serve me the hot and not those rocky cold ice chilling behind the glass. In fact, I counted as many as 8 employees chilling there, no wonder they baked multiple more. 

I came into my audacity and asked them to give us hot ones and they said they sold these cold like this.  The cheese tarts taste like rubber. I, wholeheartedly with so much human faith, ignored the previous ratings and wanted to try since it was "hot and new". I apologize but this shop is tawdry and should be titled "cold and new".
author: Trinny T.

description: Must try in SF! The lines aren't too bad. They had both the original and matcha tarts available. They're $3+ each which is kinda pricey in my opinion. Be careful when biting into the tart because the cheese will ooze all over. It's sooo good warm and isn't too cheesy. It has a hint of salt. I also took one home to refrigerate which still tasted good (more like a cheesecake) but the tart crust became hard.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Every time I walk by there's a line. I've seen it many times on IG posts. Today, there was a small line at 7pm so I gave it a try.

I was underwhelmed. It's not entirely their fault that their product has been hyped up. I've read many reviews and it seems to be a mixed experience.

The filling is like sugar + cream cheese. If you've ever made cream cheese frosting, this is exactly the taste and texture of the baked cheese tart filling...maybe the texture is a little more fluffy but pretty much tastes the same.

The tart itself was a crispy hard cookie...and while their were toppings available I found it did not "help" the tart taste better or worse.

We also ordered a coffee which the hubs gives a . That's why I give it a 3 and not a 2.

Don't think I'll go back to get another. Simply because it wasn't that memorable. The service however was...‍ they probably have some things to work out.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I have seen the phenom in the mall twice already. I have also seen the tarts on Instagram. We tried the other time but it was sold out. So this time we came early on a Sunday morning - a brisk walk from SoMa to here was a goo enough of a reason to justify why we needed these tarts. Still it's a 20 minute wait.

Long line again. $45 for a dozen including tax. Very expensive if you ask me. I chatted with the cashier. She told me that they are from Hokkaido, I was there a few years ago, and had similar but not the same tarts. This store was established only in 2014. Not too sweet but definitely falls into the dessert category. It's very cheesy, when warm, the cheese melts in your mouth. There are a few ways to eat them. Including freeze them in the fridge. We also topped it with cinnamon, chocolate and caramel sauce. 

It's already in Asia - namely Taiwan, Singapore, Indonesia, Vietnam and Hong Kong and also Shanghai. Turns out it's in my office building in Shanghai. No wonder it looked familiar. I have passed it perhaps a months ago when I was in our Shanghai office. Doh! Missed that one. But it's not Malaysia, which is a bummer as I'm likely headed to Malaysia for work in a month. Though I'll also be in Singapore and Shanghai soon so that could serve as a back up plan should I not plan for another 20 minute wait here in SF.

Now unlike Beard Papa which started its US journey in New York and took years to come to SF, this is the very first USA outpost. So if you want the real thing and not headed to Asia soon, this is your best bet!

I think the reason it costs more here than in Asia it's because it's been flown out here from Japan. I like that it's not made here because you know at some point someone will mess up the recipe, and make it too sweet for Americans. I'm glad that they kept the recipe intact here. 

Kids like them because it's something different. If you ask me, I still like Beard Papa more. They offer cream puffs with eclaire surface, and you get the fresh cream fillings and it cost also $3.50 each. We will see if the hype will die down. But for now, the kids were happy that they have now a dozen to fill their cheesy cravings with.
author: Victoria E.

description:
These cheese tarts are imported from Japan, brushed with egg wash, then baked a second time.

1. I was able to skip the line on grand opening day to try these, which I'm so appreciative of because that line can still be a little ridiculous.
2. Very comparable to cheesecake, but the texture is a lot softer and flufflier. The flavor of the filling has the perfect balance of sweet and tart. My favorite thing about these tarts is that they're good hot or cold. I placed my leftover tarts in the fridge and the next day, they were still yummy. The filling was just as fluffy, but a bit more dense.
3. The shell of any tart is my favorite. I like that these cheese tart shells aren't flakey. They have a chew and are slightly buttery and eggy.
4. Would I wait in line for these? No.
5. Are they worth $3.50 a piece? No. They are waaaay too small.
6. Would I buy a cheese tart ever again? Yes.
7. Yes, because I want to try their chocolate cheese tart.
author: Tammy P.

description:
The short: delicious cheesecake tart worth it if line is short

The first time I stopped by was around the grand opening and the line was too crazy. On the second time, they had sold out. On the third time, I finally got to try one! Third time's a charm?! 

The line process is fast. Say how many you would like. There are other flavors available too, depending on availability. 

As I bit in, I loved the crunch on the outside with the light fluffiness of goodness on the inside. The tart was at a good level of sweetness for me.

Tip: Even though the mall closes at 8:30, head there before 8 to get the last ones before they sell out and close shop when they run out. (Haven't been there earlier in the day so I don't know what the line is like.)

Verdict: get there before they run out! Ready to go back for round two!
author: Catherine W.

description:
My friend bought some cheese tarts for me and my family for my birthday! We ended up bringing them to the Giants game so my first cheese tart experience was good (not amazing) because they were a bit cold. I liked the cheese tart, but I don't think I would crave it regularly. However, the next day, I had one that was heated with a toaster oven and I fell in love! 

The cheese tarts are the perfect hybrid between a cheesecake and an egg tart. The inside is perfectly fluffy, light, and airy, and the "crust" is more like a cookie. I want to eat them all the time!! I wish I could have tried the chocolate, but I heard they're coming out with strawberry soon! The only bad thing is that they are a bit expensive. Recently I went on a Friday around 12:30 pm and waited only 10 mins in line, so the line isn't too bad anymore!
author: Tara A.

description:
We went about 2 months ago.
So we heard about these tarts. My gf is a big fanatic about japanese food so she wanted to try it. 
First off the line was not too long but once we went in line it started to grow. They do move slowly because I think people buy a tons of these.
We tried the original and green tea. My gf isnt a fan of the green tea. But we loved the original. Nice creamy and tasty. The crust really makes these tarts. Overal we did like the original. If we are in the area sure but it isnt something we would go out our way to get.
author: R. L.

description:
I found this place because I saw that there was a line for some sort of food, and like a good SF citizen, I went ahead and joined the queue without really knowing what it was for. 

I ordered a couple of the regular cheese tarts since they were all out of the other flavors. I had one warm and then another a couple days later, cold from the refrigerator. I confess that while I loved the flavor, I didn't really like the super soft texture of the filling--I think I wanted it to be more like Japanese cheesecake, which is fluffy but a little less wet? I know you're thinking "but aren't things always better when they're WET and moist?" In this case, though, the filling seemed goopy- like a cross between egg custard and cheesecake. Clearly lots of people love this texture, but it just wasn't for me.
author: Jean L.

description:
Deeeelicious fluff of cheese tarts!!

Saw this establishment on a random Facebook video and have been wanting to try this place out for a long time! I was here on a Saturday afternoon and had to wait in line for about 10 minutes; not too bad. Price is a bit steep at $3.50 each. Ended up buying a box for $20 (save a buck). These tarts are definitely something new to Cali. Checked out their IG page and it looks like some locations carry other flavors like chocolate & strawberry. Only the cheese tart option was available at the time of my visit. 

Would highly recommend if you're in the area!
author: Mei W.

description:
Be still my heart! The FIRST location of Bake in the USA is open!!!

I first tried Bake in Singapore and fell instantly in LOVE w these decadent little cheese tarts! I especially love them when they are warm and just outta the oven. They literally melt in your mouth at first bite. 

I cant wait til they expand and come to southern CA so I don't have to come up to SF to get 'em!
author: Alma P.

description:
Bake Cheese Tart has the fluffiest cheese tart I've ever tasted! This cheese tart was not what I expected. My friends and I thought it was going to be similar to an egg tart but not at all. There is a very crispy exterior shell that is a result of being double baked. As I bit into this tiny morsel, warm, foamy, airy, light cream cheese mousse oozed into my mouth. It was a pleasant surprise, very tasty, and satisfying! If you haven't had it, it's totally worth trying! It was really quick to get. 

Luckily there was a short line when we visited because I have passed by when there was a long line that stretched around the corner to the doors that are next to the place. Unfortunately they had sold out of the strawberry flavor! :( They were making more but it would be another 20 minute wait. For $3.50 each, it's a good treat! We got the 6 piece box (which is a dollar off) and an extra single one because we had 7 in our group. We all really liked it, and I would totally come back to try the strawberry flavor!
author: Katrine U.

description:
The cheese tart crust - crunchy and sweet like a crispy cookie at room temperature. 

Original cheese tart- cheesy and creamy. Fluffy at room temperature. When heated for 10 seconds, it becomes a runny, white liquid collapsed onto the softened crust. This is my favorite of the two flavors.

Strawberry cheese tart- mm, creamy strawberry goodness that reminded me of strawberry yogurt. 

These are a little too sweet imo but if you like baked goods, these are worth trying. 

A weekday morning is a good time to avoid the lines.
author: Amy T.

description:
Limited edition Matcha cheese tart is delicious! 

It's a little bitter than the original cheese tart but it leaves pleasant green tea aftertaste in your mouth.
author: Es L.

description:
I was downtown for an appointment and was craving dessert. Saw that this place was at the Westfield and knew I had to try it!

It was Noon and the line was already around the corner almost to the BART entrance! I was in line for about 40 mins. They only had 3 people getting the tarts ready, 1 person packing the tarts, and only 1 cashier. 

Since I waited so long I decided to get 2 boxes of 6, which came out to $45.57! I don't think they allow you to get more than that. Anyway, pretty pricey, but I'm not downtown often so it was worth it to me. 

The cheese tart was so smooth and fluffy! The perfect cheesecake texture, but light. The crust was baked perfectly too! I know they're not freshly made on the spot because someone said they're shipped over. But, nonetheless, they were great!

I would definitely come back and wouldn't mind the wait again!
author: Fallon P.

description:
Yes, there is hype for this dessert spot. But I'm a believer and will always be down to grab a box from here when I'm in the Westfield shopping center!

If you're a fan of light, semi-sweet Japanese desserts then go try out a cheese tart! I've only tasted the ORIGINAL tarts and they're pretty tasty -- like a combo of cheesecake, pudding, and egg tarts. I like to grab a box and stash them in the fridge. For a little more indulgent dessert texture, try freezing them! The custard/cream gets thicker and more cheesecake-like. 

I've always visited during late weekday afternoons/early evenings as I typically go after work. I never had to wait more than 10 minutes in line. The staff works pretty fast at boxing up your treats. Unfortunately my late visits mean that I missed out on the seasonal flavors -- I still need to try the matcha! 

I love grabbing a box for snacking at home, or bringing one for a party/housewarming!
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Where there's a line, get in it!! I did walk by and said no thanks but ended up walking by later and the line was shorter. I had just finished dinner and needed dessert. Even though I was stuff I had to get my hands on one of the tarts. Oh boy, it was fantastic. It certainly caught me off guard. It was delicious and having one is not right. You'll need more than that. Though it might break the bank to buy multiple but how often do you get these cheese tarts?!! Well I will be back again to get more and even if I'm not in the area I will make it a point to come even just for this tart. Just expect to pay the price of the food because it's in a mall and in San Francisco.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Finally, SF is slowly catching up with the rest of the world - but at a snails pace.

The much anticipated Bake had grand opened inside Westfield earlier this month and I heard the lines were insane. So, I gave it a few weeks before even bothering bc this is definitely not worth a crazy ass wait time to me personally.

Came on a Sunday afternoon and of course there was a line. Thankfully, it was literally less than a 10min wait. I seriously wouldn't wait any longer. 

The cheese tarts were good, but nothing orgasmic. The crust just doesn't do it for me. Wish it were actually crisp to the bite. But it's only crispy around the top. At least the cheese filling isn't overly sweet. *sigh* These tarts just don't compare to the ones I've had in Japan and in Hong Kong. Sad, but true. 

As for pricing... yikes. They do cost a pretty penny or two. Lol. One dozen for $40+ though... Seriously?! $40 gets you at least 2 dozen overseas... smh.
author: Ann T.

description:
Came here on Sunday evening around 4:30pm. Decent sized line (15 minute wait).

Service // friendly front of house staff 
Love that it's open and you can see the tarts being laid out and baked. 

Smells wonderful! The tarts are 3.50 each or 6 for 21.00. When I came they only had the original but apparently they do special flavors like chocolate as well. 

Love that if you buy a box of 6 it comes in a nicely packaged box and bag. This would make a nice gift! 

The tarts were so yummy! The crust is a shortbread cookie like delight and the inside is some kind of creamy cheese cloud fluff. I will probably come back to either treat myself to another tart or to give it as a gift to someone's
author: Emily T.

description: This store is very popular since it opened. I always see it on IG. We stopped by, for the new item: Matcha Cheese Tart. I am a fan of it!!! They used high-quality matcha to make this dessert, but it still overprices. That's why I gave 4 stars.
author: Anny L.

description:
Pricey but affordable sweet treat is the way I'd put it. I'd heard about this spot (soo much hype) from friends, and happened to walk by on a Sunday when there wasn't too much of a line.

The crust was super crunchy and fairly sweet, although not overly so that my sweetness threshold was reached. It was good in a memorable sort of way. The cheese itself was somewhat ricotta-y (not sure where all these comparisons to egg tarts are because it's not similar at all), with a light sweetness. Think of the texture as a very, very fluffy cheesecake. Portion-wise, rather small (though cute), and that's coming from someone who likes small desserts in general.

Disappointingly, even though they were baking the tarts fresh in an oven, they were boxing up the cooled (read: room temperature) ones, which made it less tasty. I would come again only if I was already in the area or looking to pick these up for a friend. 3.5/5 for me, with the caveat that it's pricey.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Thankfully the hype has died down a bit.  Waited in a short line for less than 5 minutes to give it a try.  It's not as swoon-worthy as the always-on-vacation Golden Gate Bakery, but it's still an indulgent treat.

Cheese Tart: It may look like an egg tart, but it's nothing like an egg tart at all.  It's more like someone put a no-bake cheesecake in the oven and it melted and got all gooey.  The crispy shell is a great firm pairing to the molten cheese gushing out.
author: Adam B.

description:
Whenever something opens for the first time in San Francisco, I know there will be a line. Luckily for me, Peter L decided to endure the wait. And I was the happy recipient. He brought the tarts to a happy hour on Friday, May 11th around 6:15pm.

I believe he waited in line for about an hour and got the max amount of tarts possible. A dozen of the original tarts and half a dozen of the chocolate ones. Pricing wise, I think they were $3.50 each? Since we got them the day after, I first tried the original at room temp. The tart was kind of a mix between a cheesecake and an egg tart. Cheesy with a slight egginess. I liked how they weren't too sweet, but there was an element that almost made them taste a touch savory. I wasn't a huge fan of that. Later, I tried both the original and chocolate after I heated them up in the toaster oven and they were better. I actually liked the chocolate one more and I'm not even a huge chocolate person. Though I believe they were made with dandelion chocolate and I adore their super dark chocolate. 

Glad I was able to try these Japanese cheese tarts. Though I'm happy I didn't have to wait in line for an hour as I don't think they are really worth the wait. Thanks Peteo for saving me some tarts!
author: Elena N.

description:
Several weeks ago we attempted to buy some cheese tarts but they sold out around 6:30p.m.  Today hubby was downtown running errands so I requested he make a detour to buy some tarts.

He swung by around 10:30a.m.  No line.  He bought 1/2 dozen.  Boxed in a two level rectangular shape box.  

We ate them for afternoon snack.  Light cheese mouse filling in a very snappy tart.

Bake Cheese Tart originated in Hokkaido Japan and they've opened outpost stores worldwide.  Seeing that we just returned from Japan two months ago, we still have all things Japanese on the brain.

At $3.50 each, it's somewhat pricey for a few bites.  A nice change as it's just enough sugar.  Not too sweet.

On Bake Cheese Tart website, it states you can eat the tart fresh, chilled, frozen, or microwave. 

I'm not sure I'll be a frequent patron, but the tart was good for the record.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Not worth my time in line!  Long line that doesn't move and one person working and one person packing. It's a horrible streamline and doesn't maximize the product and not cost effective.  You have to get a certain number of it too.  It costs about $3.20 (correct me if I'm wrong), each. 

Cheese tart is aye okay!  It's not heavy like a regular American cheesecake nor is it light like an egg tart.  It's a good equilibrium.  It doesn't make me crave for more. Sizable and notable.  

They ship it from Japan - how original.  

Good, but not the greatest for me to yearn for more. Overhyped.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Tried their special MATCHA this weekend, and I was in H E A V E N. It was a little more runny compared to the regular, which was a little weird, but it tasted delicious nonetheless. I love you so matcha!!!
author: Vickie Z.

description: The first time I stopped by, everything was already sold out. Luckily I was back in SF and my friend was craving cheese tarts. We went around 2pm and they still had plenty of cheese tarts left. The taste itself was pretty good BUT I'm not sure if it was worth the price. I've had less expensive cheese tarts from other bakeries before and they taste just as good. I wonder if it's cause this shop is originally from Japan. At $3.50 a piece, they are definitely trying to rob me. LOL but at least I can say I've tried it! I probably won't get it again because it's just way too expensive for a single piece of cheese tart.
author: Debby S.

description:
I came here the Thursday and Friday before Mother's Day, attempting to purchase cheese tarts for a part of my mom's Mother's Day gift. 

Thursday's Visit: 
I arrived at 8pm and there was a short line because they were almost sold out. According to one of the employees who was standing at the end of the line, if everyone bought 12, then they would sell out right before the person in front of me. My friend and I still waited regardless in case there would be leftovers for us. Plus, it was a very short wait. Unfortunately, we weren't able to purchase any that night but fine by me. Also, the employee who is a senior at Balboa attending UCB in the f was super friendly! 

Friday's Visit: 
I arrived around 6:30pm and the line was out of the Bart entrance. After waiting about 10 minutes, we received a card with how many we would purchase. It guarantee that we would be able to purchase the amount that we requested. It took my friend and I about 30 minutes to finally get to the front. I ordered half a dozen. 

The cheese tart itself is amazing. My mom, who is very picky and not easily impressed LOVES the cheese tarts. It's not overly cheesy or sweet, which she prefers. It's enjoyable both hot and frozen. I love it too! 

I came back the Friday of Memorial Day weekend. They didn't give out the vouchers. I was almost to the front of the line after waiting almost 15 minutes when they announced that they were almost sold out. I was one person away from the person who bought the last 3. Surely I was disappointed that they didn't announce earlier that they were close to selling out. There was a lot of people behind me too. It was only 6:50pm. 

I advise checking with the front before lining up especially towards the end of closing. Save yourself some time in case they sell out. 

It's quite pricey at $3.50 each, but definitely worth a try.
author: Yi Xian R.

description:
I kinda want to leave a bad review so people don't come here and make the line longer...

The line wrapped to the Bart entrance, and that was after showing up when the mall opened at 11. 

The line also moves really slow. Slow enough that if you're with a small child, or a very hangry boyfriend, they will complain. Alot. 

Everything is behind glass so when you're trying to take your arty pics for your Instagram story, you'll always have a slight glare, that always just slightly ruins the photo. 

You'll also get random old people coming up to you asking if you're in line for pastries, and how they're 'very expensive'. Then mumble 'kids' as they walk away taking in the longass line wrapped around the corner. 

If you go with an old person be prepared that they'll tell you how back in their day, they had to walk 15 miles to get to the bakery. In a blizzard.

It's in the mall. Mall food court to be exact and they sell out of the chocolate tarts very quickly. 

All in all, don't come here and just add to the line, selling out my beloved chocolate tarts. 

Can I interest you in a mediocre lobster roll or poke bowl across the way?
author: Mandi W.

description:
So happy to see that this place is open! I used to go to the one in Japan and the formula is consistent. Taste just like the ones overseas!

Came here after work a week ago and the line was only a few people long. It didn't take more than 15 mins to grab my tarts and go. They did run out of chocolate tarts though by the end of the day so if you want those you might want to go early. I was okay with only eating the OG flavor. 

These tarts are a little pricey at $3.50/piece, but a nice treat. They're fluffy and creamy and not too sweet. You can also freeze them and eat it that way.
author: Junella T.

description:
The first time I tried a Japanese cheese tart was in Canada at Uncle Tetsu and I felt in love with this dessert dish so when I found out that this Japanese cheese tart was opening up in SF, I HAD to try it. I waited until the hype died down a little and went on a weekday to avoid the extremely long line and the shop running out of cheese tart and it paid off. I went in the afternoon (around 3pm) on the Tuesday after Labor Day weekend and the line was not long at all (I only had 3 people in front of me). There was also plenty of cheese tart to go around. What I did notice immediately was that there is currently a limit to how much you can buy per day. They limited each person to 6 pieces per day and a 6 pieces box cost roughly $20-21. 

I tried both the Matcha and regular flavor. The Matcha flavor was very rich in Matcha. I think the Matcha was way too rich that I ended up not like it. However, the regular cheese tart was pretty good and very similar to Uncle Tetsu cheese tart. I would definitely recommend the regular cheese tart to people.

Now whether or not it is worth about $3.50 per cheese tart is a different story. In my opinion, I think the price is a bit too high and I think a factor of that is that the shop is in Westfield SF, which potentially have very high rent so they would also have to mark up their price. Now, would I pay $3.50 for it when I want it? Of course I would, but then again, I would spend quite a bit for good food.
author: Chenny O.

description:
OhhhhMMMMGEEEE!  They taste so good!  

I came here during my lunch hour and waited 25 minutes in the slowest production line I've ever seen.  1 cashier, 1 person filling the orders but 3 persons baking the goods.  They need to re-evaluate the lines to make them move faster.  It's critical to get to that tart faster!

Let's talk about that tart.  It's a cheesecake.  A little fluffy, creamy cheesecake with a buttery cookie like crust.  It's OMGEEE!  I want more!!!

Expensive!  $3.50 for the regular flavor.  $3.65 for the limited edition chocolate flavor.

I know I will be back for another bite of that tart!
author: Jenny T.

description: Great place for an afternoon snack - coffee and cheesecake tart. I was intrigued by this new place from Japan and had to try it. I went several times for different flavors and every time there was a small line. It goes fast since there are only a few items on the menu. I'm not sure why some cheesecakes come out more pale and some are more toasted on top. The cheesecake filling itself is the stuff. It's very fluffy and not the denseness usually associated w/ cheesecake. Strange for a production that seems so uniform. The strawberry flavor was not that strong and it had a few small pieces of freeze dried strawberries on top. Each tart sets you back about $4.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
How could anyone turn down these fluffy yellow tarts?? There was a pretty long line when I visited but it moves quick. It was around a 10 minute wait, and there were about 20-25 people in line. Currently they only have the original flavor but Strawberry is coming out in July.
The filling is very soft, almost like the Chinese egg tarts but instead of egg, it's made with cream cheese. When we bought them, they were room temperature (and delicious) but they do have recommendations for eating it chilled or reheated. I wish I had more self control to save one to have chilled. Oh well, maybe next time!!
author: Athena L.

description:
Stumbled upon the spot when I was heading to the bart through the Westfield Shopping Center and was so intrigued by the line of people and the cute display...made a mental note, got a box the next time I was in the area and was soooo delighted! 

The tarts are a wonderful blend of textures without being too sweet. And the dessert itself is so interesting if you eat it cold versus warmed, etc! I love it straight from the bakery - they have a great crisp shell with a little molten cheesecake filling. I've practically become a brand ambassador - telling everyone of my love for them. They're also perfect for social functions - such a crowd pleaser!
author: Annie S.

description:
i'm a huge fan of cheese tarts and when i found out that bake cheese tart was opening up shop in california i was ecstatic! then i got sad because it was in nor-cal and not so-cal. luckily on my most recent visit i was able make a pit stop at bake cheese tart. 

got myself 6 cheese tarts. 3 original and 3 match flavor. $20.08 without tax. matcha is more pricey as one is $3.65 and original $3.50. personally, my favorite is the original cheese tart. if you are a fan of cheese tart then you gotta pay them a visit! matcha tart not worth the visit. original cheese tart is definitely worth the visit! two thumbs up my friends! 

tips:
*located in the mall
*located in the food court
*cash and credit card accepted
*two flavors original and matcha
author: Lisa D.

description:
I finally bit the bullet and waited in the massive line. It was about a 30 minute wait at 5:30pm. 

The line moved gradually, although I overheard that the chocolate tarts were already sold out. I was slightly disappointed, but ultimately wanted to try the original cheese tart.

The cheese tarts are $3.50 each, $21 for 6--there is no discount for buying more. They also limit you to a dozen per person.

As I got to the front of the line, it was obvious why they were taking so long. There were at least 5 employees turned away folding boxes or glazing the tarts and only 2 working at the register. 

They pack it to order, which is nice, but also an inefficient use of time. There should be employees packing customers orders so when they get to the register, all they have to do is pay.

The employee packing the tarts was really friendly and was happy to pack the tarts that were perfectly golden brown! I don't know why they're selling some that clearly look half burnt.

Onto the cheese tarts - they're pretty tiny. I tried it both room temperature and chilled, and I honestly think they taste SO much better after being chilled in the fridge. The room temp tarts taste like whipped and runny cream cheese, whereas the chilled tarts tasted like a cheesecake with a nice shortbread crust. 

Overall - 3.5 stars. Good cheese tarts, just a bit pricey along with a terrible wait time.
author: Shirley H.

description:
After months of wanting to try this place, my boyfriend and I finally got the chance to after a long day of shopping in the city. The line at that time wasn't bad. Matter fact, we only waited 3-5 minutes.

The cheese tarts are pretty pricey, in my opinion. $3.50 apiece or $21 for 6pcs. They're pretty good though as they are smooth, gooey, fluffy, and, of course, cheesy. The crust was tasty also.  It was actually my favorite part. I still, however, don't think they are worth $3.50 each since they are small, hence the 4 stars only.
author: Celina A.

description:
I've never had a cheese tart before this. They're sooo good! The inside is light and fluffy and the flavor is delicious. Definitely eat it hot and fresh. If you take some home, don't make the mistake of microwaving. The crust becomes soft. 

We thought about getting the different flavors but it turns out those are just sauces that you can put on top after you receive your tarts. I personally think they don't think any sauce additions.

Came on a Saturday afternoon and the wait was maybe like 10 minutes at the most. It moves really fast.

The price of 6 per tart is the same as buying 1. The only difference is that 6 comes in a cardboard box where individual ones come in a paper bag
author: Sophia L.

description:
Always a line.

Always.

But, hey it's closer then going to Japan for one of these cheese tarts right?

I want to say a huge YUM to the original cheese tart. It tastes like a small cheesecake, and it's always baked fresh.

The chocolate one tastes like a cross between a chocolate cheesecake and a thick chocolate mousse.

At $3.50 prepare to shell out some dough (get it LOL) for these treats, but it's worth it.

Solid pie like crust with a smooth cheese filling--be prepared for the wait, and while you're at it buy more than one, because I don't think one is enough. Your friends, co-workers, family, and you just might want a second!
author: Jack R.

description:
Delicious but be careful!! The cheese tart melts in your mouth like creamy foam. I didn't expect it to be so soft and accidentally dropped half of it (goodbye $3.50 a pop). Otherwise it was perfectly flavored!
I also tried the matcha flavor, but cheese is the way to go. The matcha tarts were a little pricier and had a strange salty flavor (along with an astringent and bitter taste but that comes with matcha). 

There is usually a line where you can see them bake the tarts; come before it gets sold out for the day!! It took about 10 minutes to get to the front on a Saturday afternoon :) I would come back only for the cheese tart!
author: Leona C.

description:
If you visit the Westfield food court often, I'm pretty sure you've notice the huge line of people forming at a certain dessert spot near the bart entrance. At first glance, it's just a huge wall of yellow boxes and glass windows. When you take a closer look you'll notice trays and trays of deliciously toasty and golden yellow cheese tarts lined up in the window. 

I came here on a Friday afternoon and the line peaked my curiosity. I had friends who lived in the city and they recommended this cheese tart place but I was never really sure where it was located. As soon as I saw the baked cheese tarts at the window, I knew I was in the right spot. The line is very intimidating and you can't help but wonder whether the wait is worth it. It stretches around the corner of the restaurant and almost to the bart station. 

The cheese tarts are great, don't get me wrong. The cheese part of the tart was a little tangy and not too sweet. It was very creamy and soft with a nice toast on the top. The crust is my favorite part. It's not flaky like an egg tart usually is, and not crumbly like the traditional cheesecake crust. I can't really describe the texture but it's very good. Although it's delicious, I don't think it's justified to wait 35 minutes or more only to buy 6. They're also quite pricey at $3.50 for one, $21 for 6. 

I would love to visit again if the line was more efficient. You wait in line to order from one cashier and the cashier assembles the boxes while you pay. I think that's why it took so long. I did like how he showed me the tarts to ensure I was satisfied with them before he boxed it up.

Overall, cheese tarts 4 Stars. If based on cheese tarts and overall experience including price/wait time, then 3.5 Stars.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Egg Tarts, Cheese Tarts, I like em all....if you're a NYC soshi this week you attended the MET ball....the lines to get these things are not short but tall..... you'll find BCT if you hook a quick left once you hit the food court at the Westfield mall....

Wait time: For those of you curious, the wait from the glass doors that lead out to Bart/muni is about 1 hour.  I'd say every order takes about two minutes to process (approximately).  I've been twice now so when you have time to kill you think about these seemingly trivial things. 

Why do I do go to places like this? In one word: CURIOSITY
