Curiosity killed the cat, The Curious case of Benjamin Button and Curious George have a new member of their club ...curious Rod. 

Saw this place on social media and I was intrigued that it was the first location in the United States. When I saw there was long multiple hour long lines, I had to see for myself what the buzz was about. 

I snagged and allowed myself to eat one of each flavor of these pint sized bites. $3.50 for 1 and 6 for $21 (if you can't do math they have it on a sign next to the cash register).

The cheese tarts are shipped frozen from Japan and at the store according to one of the employees they glaze them and place the egg yolk and then bake them? (sounds feasible). 

The consistency of the cheese tart tastes more "liquidy" than your standard egg tart. Since the lines are so long you are sure to get a fresh/warm tasting egg tart. To me it tastes like a light cheesecake-ish almost like the famous "Zanze's " cheesecake  in the Inner Sunset. 

How was the taste? Solid but I have it in the middle of the pack of my rankings below.  $3.50 as others have noted seems a tad bit expensive and the taste while different isn't knock your socks off good but it's a solid alternative to the conventional egg tart. Would I wait in a long line for this place? No way , but if there was no line I might snag one. 

Of the two flavors I think I liked the chocolate one more because it was flavorful but not too "rich" for me. The "regular" was good as well so I'd encourage you to try both to see for yourself (especially if you wait in that long line). 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank places in the SF Bay Area that sell Egg Tart...yes Egg Tart. Obviously given the nature of the food most of these places are in SF or Oakland Chinatown. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba,Tacos, Ice Cream,  Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?).  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

1 Mr.Bread
2 Golden Gate Bakery
3 Yummy Bakery 
4 New Hollywood Bakery
5 Bake Cheese Tart - yes I know it's not tech a egg tart 
6 Ruby King Bakery
7 Napolean Super Bakery
8 Sheng Kee Bakery 
9 Wonder Food Bakery 
10 Sum Yee Pastry
11 Grand Mission Donuts and Bakery
author: Rod M.

description:
Born In Hokkaido and made its way through Asia. I seen it last year when I was in Thailand but failed to go. I roll up at Westfield mall and there is about 60 people in line. 

I text my foodie friend if they have Baked in NYC and she said yes. Her first time was in Signapore. I was convinced Yas this has to be good. Opened up on Friday 2 days ago and I heard the line was 2hours. Thank goodness it was at least a 40min wait.

Starring through the window like a little kid wondering how many am I getting. The limit is 12 lol they have the original and chocolate at $3.50 a pop.

My first bite crust tasted like short bread, inside creamy cheese like a half baked cheesecake and warm in the middle.
That bad boy melted in my mouth and wanted seconds lol
author: Kathy V.

description:
What's different compared to others? They have the FLUFFIEST cheese tarts. The moment you stick your tongue into the custard, you can feel how light yet creamy that tart is. Definitely better than Uncle Tetsu. 

Get at least 3 if you're really hungry. You can also buy them fresh or frozen! So awesome!

Original cheese tarts are the way to go! I didn't care for the flavored cheese tarts.
author: Mandy W.

description:
$23 for 6 cheese tarts is definitely a bit rich for my blood but I had to hop in line today to see what the hype was about. Glad to report that they are good but not spectacular and definitely not worth the price for me to want to come back for more. 

This place sells Hokkaido baked cheese tarts which means you can expect a very balanced treat. Not too sweet and not too overpowering in flavor with just the right balance of crunch from the crust with the fluffiness of the soft cheese filling. The big pull for me today versus previous times when I've walked by here was the word MATCHA covering the wall behind the counter. Regular cheese tarts are just interesting but matcha cheese tarts are irresistible! I ordered 6 comprised of 4 matcha and 2 regular. They actually have a sign limiting each customer to only 6 of the matcha tarts so immediately I thought, "this sh** must be bomb if they gotta cut people off from ordering too many so everyone can get in on the tart action!" I'm clearly susceptible to suggestive selling and therefore the ideal consumer because I only planned to buy four but walked away with their standard box of six. 

Line is usually around the corner and moves really slowly. There is one register so they help one person at a time. Definitely something you shouldn't try to squeeze in on your lunch break unless you plan on possibly skipping lunch and having only tarts. Service is fantastic though once it's your turn. They are very friendly and package your tarts perfectly to go. 

Now for the tarts. The filling tastes like a whipped and fluffy cheesecake filling. The regular tart just tastes like a plain New York cheesecake without the heavy weigh you down feeling you get from a cheesecake. The matcha was delicious. Very strong matcha flavor but you could still taste the cream cheese and just as light and fluffy. Almost like a matcha cream cheese mousse is the only way I can describe it. The crust--oh the crust!!! This was the best part. I would come back here just for a bag of crusts! It's a light, buttery crunchy texture that only Japanese pastries get right. Not too sweet and really the perfect counter to the soft filling. I just ate another one before writing this review and I definitely think they taste better cooled off. They come warm with each order and the filling is actually a little runny and unappetizing as a result. If you go, get a box and have a few later so you can see for yourself. 

The biggest scam? The ladies at the counter actually tried to sell me the frozen cheese tart saying how it tastes like ice cream cake and how my son would love it. Please don't try to pawn of yesterday's unsold tarts as today's frozen cheese tart. I would be happy to try one for $1; otherwise, give me the fresh stuff and back away. I'm good to go. 

These are good but not life altering, especially for the price. Worth checking out and probably makes for a great snack after a long day of shopping while you're at the mall.
author: Betty R.

description:
Came when the mall opened and was second in line, and ordered half a dozen. Beautiful presentation in packaging. 

I love all kinds of egg tarts. Chinese ones Portuguese ones. These Japanese egg tarts are definitely like a light cream cheese. Not too sweet and light. Loved the crunchy crust. They can be refrigerated or frozen. But since i was sharing and didn't have access to a frig all day, they were still great at the end of the day. 

I happened to go by at the end of the day and there was about 20 people in line and still a lot of tarts to sell.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Tried out KB Bake on the 3rd day it opened in SF.  It's inside the Westfield Mall Downtown, foodcourt Bloomingdale side, by Sur La Table/Cako.

Only 1 cashier and they take a long time because the box they use it hard to put the tarts in.  I think that's why it takes so long.  The tarts were already made and there's only 2 choices: regular cream cheese tart or chocolate made from Dandelion Chocolate in SF.

I got 3 regular and 3 chocolate.  Regular is $3.50 ea, chocolate I think were $3.65?  not sure, it's not listed on my receipt, I just remember they run up higher.

They charge tax too so it was a lot more than $21 that I was expecting to pay.

Regular - crust is crispy like a shortbread cookie, creamy and fluffy, a bit tangy.  Chocolate I seemed to like better, same crust, chocolate blended well and not as tangy.  Chocolate should be on the menu for 3 months.

I asked about green tea tart a lady in line said they have in Hong Kong, they don't know if they'll have it.

Suppose to refrigerate any leftovers.  Can be eaten cold, frozen, or warmed up in toaster oven.

I might go back, not in any hurry.
author: Ann L.

description:
Bake Cheese Tart originates from Japan, and there are stores in Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines. This is the first US store, and it's conveniently located right by the Powell BART station, inside the Westfield mall. 

Price: almost $4 for one, $21 for 6
Flavors: chocolate and original cheese
* if you're a chocolate lover, I did like the chocolate more. They're limited edition and made with Dandelion chocolate*

I waited an HOUR for these (I don't usually wait an hour for anything), so of course I left with a box of 6. Tons of people commented on the Bake bag I was carrying around all day. 

The hype is real. I already ate 3 today, and I will be back.
author: Corinna T.

description:
5 Star for taste 
1 Star for service and sense of urgency from staff 

I loved these tarts in Japan so I came for the grand opening today and waited 3 hours to purchase 12 classic and 6 chocolate tarts which were the maximum allowed per guest. 

I lined up at 11:15am, store opened at 12 and the line didn't actually start moving until about 1230. Granted there was a long line that extended into the bart station but the line really should have moved a lot faster than it did. When I got closer to the front and was able to observe the transactions, it really seemed like there was no order and direction. There were plenty of tarts and plenty of staff, but the line moved so incredibly slow!! Honestly the tarts are amazing but due to the lack of urgency from the staff. I would recommend for people to wait until the hype dies down before visiting. I would have been really nice for management to have done something to thank the customer who waited 3+ hours for their tarts.
author: Serena L.

description:
Located conveniently in the Westfield Mall Foodcourt!

Waited in an hour long line and it was worth it! Lol. I've tried these melting cheese tarts in Japan (from mini Pablo) and I can confirm these are just as delicious!

They're definitely more on the pricier side - about $4 each. They only had two flavors - original cheese & chocolate. They're both SUPER delicious - but the chocolate was really rich and to die for. I'm hoping they'll have more flavors!

P.s currently they have a max purchase of 12 original & 6 chocolate per person.

Pro tip: Eat them while they're still hot for the best experience :)
author: Melanie T.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but I ate a bite of disappointment, unfortunately. I've tried premium cheese tarts in Tokyo on my trip to Japan last year and I loved it. I was quite exited to hear that a chain was coming to the Bay Area.

Bake Cheese Tart is located inside Westfield Mall, so you would have to pay to parking in the garage for $20-$25 (depending how long you stay) or uber since it's really hard to find free public parking. The line wasn't as bad when I went, since I decided to try this place a lot later after they announced their grand opening.

The new flavor that came out when the day I came was their matcha, and it just wasn't that great. Or maybe I'm just not a fan of matcha? I tried their original tarts too, but it just tasted too gooey to my liking and the cheese flavor is a little overwhelming.

Maybe their other flavors are better, but I won't be returning anytime soon :(
author: Crystal N.

description:
We came around 6pm on a Wednesday. They ran out of chocolate tarts and the line was still wrapping around into the bart station. Wait was only 20 minutes and the line went faster than I thought. 

The cheese tart was so yummy. Perfect amount of sweet to savory ratio complemented with the taste of gooey and soft cheese on the inside.

Cost is on the pricier side for what it is, but I'll definitely be back when the hype dies down.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Love this place. Taste the same as the one in Japan. There is always a line waiting for cheese tart but it moves fast! 
Fresh baked cheese tart! They also have seasonal favor and this month is green tea. 
It is pricy tho. Like $3.50 each
author: I C.

description: Kind of expensive for what it is, but it is flown in from Japan so that's probably the reason for the price. I like trying their special flavors, strawberry and matcha being some of my favorites so far. Their tarts are on the liquid-y side, so don't expect it to be all solid (unless you refrigerate or freeze it and then take a bite into it). I come here often because it's close to where I work, but wouldn't go way out of my way to get it.
author: Megan K.

description:
Some people prefer cheese tarts when cold, others prefer fresh out of the oven. When it comes to Bake, it doesn't really matter. You'll get the same result:  *buys another dozen*

Highly recommend the Matcha Cheese Tart! Keep an eye on the line and don't forget to get napkins!
author: Michael D.

description:
On a Fridays-afternoon, the wait was about 45 minutes for my friends and me!  But I was told that this is a modest wait compared to how long the line can get during peak hours (up to two hours).  

Getting to the cheese tart--they are absolutely divine.  I was a skeptic at first, because I didn't understand what the hype was about (arguably still don't) but the cheese tarts were certainly scrumptious.  

The texture is very airy, fluffy and light, which is not apparent when you are judging it's overall composition.  

Definitely has a unique flavor and texture.  But I wouldn't wait for more than 15 minutes to purchase a box full, especially because they are also quite pricey individually (~ $3.00).  This location also offers a chocolate-cheese-tart variation which I have not tried but heard that they are quite popular and sell out quickly.
author: An Thien T.

description:
I came here with a friend on a weekday during lunch and thought that the queue would be long but it wasn't. It actually moved quite fast and we managed to get the front in a matter of minutes. While in line I was able to see them make the tarts - they looked so much like Chinese egg custard tart I was excited to try it.

Since we had a hearty bowl of ramen we decided to split one. 

I'm not normally a fan of cheesecake but I actually liked this better than regular cheesecake. The tart had a soufflé like texture and the crust was dense like a cookie.

We finished off the tart in no time and we decided we are coming back to have one each.
author: Nette T.

description:
I have never eaten anything like this before, and I typically hate all things cream cheese, but this was SO good.

They are the perfect picture of sweet and savory and the right ratio of crust to filling.  The original was my favorite, but I also enjoyed the matcha option.

I'm going to try one of them cold and see how it is.  That's my one sadness....that they're served just at room temperature, rather than a little warm or a little chilled.

I would definitely come back here, even if the scale hates me for it.

P.S. More flavors would be great!  The chocolate seems like it was very short-lived :(
author: Tay H.

description:
BEST EVER.

My boss bought these last week. She works in SF. She said this place is originally from Japan. Man they know how to make a cheese tart. The crust is so good! Just like a shortbread cookie. There's a little card that comes with your order on how to refrigerate and eat. If you eat it fresh the crust is like a cookie. If you put it in the fridge and eat it the next day, it's like a "cheesecake bite" , if you put it in the freezer it's like a ice cake. So I haven't tried it refrigerated, but either way it'll be good! 

My boss said it's located in the mall and there's still long lines. Highly recommended.
author: Justine A.

description:
Quick Summary:
- Line is still long (took 35 minutes or so)
- Ordering 6 will get the box, 3 will only get a paper bag
- Better eaten on the day it was ordered

I've heard of the opening of a Japanese cheesecake tart store in Westfield, but when I visited on the day it opened, the line extended outside of the mall and to the ticket gates of BART. 

I finally decided to go after the limited time offer the chocolate cheesecake (collaborated with Dandelion), so I missed it. (There are rumors that they are going to sell strawberry).

Compared to the line I saw on opening day, the line still goes around the store, but it was short enough to wait before your patience thins. I ordered three because there were three of us, but instead of the cute boxes for 6 tarts, they cheesecakes were placed in a large paper bag. Luckily, I had a relative who carefully carried the bag home so the cheesecakes remained intact and still picture perfect. 

We tried two eating methods: eating it within a day and one storing it in the refrigerator. We agreed that eating it on the day it was ordered was best. Otherwise, the cooled down cheesecake tasted how we make at home (translation: nothing too special). 
If eaten on the same day, the tart is light and crisp, the outer portion of the cheesecake is fluffy, but when one takes a bite at the center the cheesecake is creamier. 

This cheesecake I would line up and order more.
author: Mito I.

description: Good cheese tarts, thankful that I didn't have to wait in line too long. They had the regular cheese tarts and the matcha cheese tarts. The matcha tarts are very green and you can totally taste the matcha. If you are not a matcha fan, then this one may not be for you.  The regular cheese tarts were divine and delicious. It was definitely the favorite at home. Service a bit slow as there were customers contesting to the way the tarts were packaged and rung up. Seriously people... there are two flavors and the prices are posted!! Would definitely come back and try seasonal flavors!
author: Alicia A.

description:
First time I walked by on a Friday afternoon one week after they opened, and the line was insane.  I passed.

Next time I walked by maybe a month after they opened on a Saturday morning and boom!  Zero line.  But I couldn't pass up the opportunity.  

Everything is great about these little tarts...  Except the price.  They are expensive.  Its worth a taste, and if you are a good baker, then after trying it you can probably recreate this delicious treat.
author: Kim C.

description:
I love bake cheese tart!!! 

As a cheesecake non-fanatic, I gotta say that this place keeps me pretty content. I think my utter dislike for cheesecakes may be due to the compact and heaviness of it. This is why I always opt for Japanese/ Asian style cheesecakes because they tend to be lighter. Bake cheese tart has a good cheesecake flavor that doesn't taste too much like cream cheese, it's nice and soft, and the short bread crust is the breadwinner of it all! This tart complements itself in every way. 

Came in around 5pm on a Wednesday night. I was lucky enough to get in line when there were only about 10 people in front of me! (Or is it dying down by now?) 

Still.... gotta say that what could've taken 5 minutes, took about triple the time. Not sure if their system is the best. One was a cashier and there was one boxing the tarts. I appreciate that they box as we order and we can see that they are boxing it fresh.... however it takes too long. Possible to have a person keep boxing? We can see them doing it anyway. Just a suggestion. - 1/2 Star for that 

Oh yeah: you can only buy a dozen each person so bring a friend to get you more! 

Took off 1/2 star because these are pricey AF!
author: Karen B.

description:
First visit and first time trying the internet famous tart. I got the classic baked cheese tart.
The presentation of the store and tart itself is clean cut and aesthetic. The cookie crust has nearly perfect edges.The cashier and server tailor to customers who seek those aspects as they ask you if the tart chosen for you is okay before packaging. 
The cheese filling was arid and creamy, on the denser side much unlike the fluffiness of whipped cream. To best describe the flavor, it is a hybrid of slightly sweet mascarpone and savory cream cheeses. The tart was very neatly filled in a crunchy butter cookie crust (not flaky pastry). Overall, the tart was tasty, but having the whole tart to myself was much too heavy.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Yes, it's pretty expensive, but I much prefer a cheese tart (or two) to a $5 cupcake.  Definitely recommend trying it at least once.  If you order 6, then you get a whole box; otherwise they'll put it in a paper bag.

Apparently you can eat this chilled or room temperature, but I much prefer eating them right away while they're fresh.  I like that it's not too sweet and the filling is delicious.
author: Shannon L.

description:
You're more likely to find a line than not, but the line isn't too bad. If it's around the corner pat the glass, you're looking at a 5-15 minute wait probably.

I'm a big fan of the matcha flavor. Wish they still had chocolate. They could stand to add a few more though.

They could be faster if they pre-packaged some boxes, but I guess it's done this way so you know you're getting them fresh. Doesn't add value to me though. They lose a star for slow service.

I wouldn't get it often, but I do like to get it as a treat if I want to show up with something nice.

Definitely works out of the fridge of freezer--less likely to fall apart on your hand that way too!
author: Paolo V.

description:
This place opened at the Westfield mall and the lines have always been a bit insane. I'm curious about places that are confident enough to offer basically just one product (kinda reminded me of Crispy Kreme donuts when they first opened and, yes, I'm that old) so as soon as I saw a relatively short line one night - I decided to line up. 

They sell one tart for $3.50 or a box for $21 (no discount except you get a nice box).  The tart itself is nice enough - fluffy cheese with nice warm baked crust.  The tart lasts 1 day at room temperature or 4 days when refrigerated.  Is it worth the hype?  Maybe. Is it worth the long line?  No.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Is it worth the line? Hard to say. 

I was impressed by the warmness and patience of the staff working there--only 2 people. 

The cheese tart itself was many things: smooth, cheesy, creamy, fluffy, and still had a slight tang, all contributing to a complex party in my mouth. 

They are pricey, so buy a bunch for later or for others to keep the price down (buying 6 makes each individual price less than just 1, for example.) 

They also give you a small handout explaining when to eat the tart and how long it'll last. 

I'll be back to try new flavors if the line/hype dies down.
author: Lizzie S.

description: The tart itself is creamy and delicious! It melts in your mouth on the first bite. But probably not worth paying $3.60 for one cheese tart.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Had to see what the hype was all about with this cheese tarts. Saw photos of these lil' tartlets floating around my instagram feed and was surprised it was located at Westfield SF centre. I'm always down for places that are bartable. I browsed the reviews and did my research before making my way here.

Subject and $$-- Japanese cheese tarts shipped from Japan, 2 current flavaflavs: original Hokkaido $3.50 each (limit 12) and chocolate $3.65 (limit 6, which sells out fast)

Location--across from Cako and Walgreens, next to the bart entrance. 

Wait time--15-30+ mins depending on what time of the day you go. Weekdays are the best time it seems like. Weekends I feel like the wait time would be a nightmare. There's only one cashier.

Made my way out here on a Thursday evening around 6:15pm. The line was pretty cray, about 30 people deep. Wrapped around the corner and past the bart sliding doors entrance. Waited about 35+ mins until I reached the front. You can see everybody at work through their glass wall. The oven on the far right, the table of tartlets hot and ready to be delicately places in a box, napkin or paper bag. 

It was apparent that chocolate was already sold out by that time bc all I could see was a sea of pale yellow slightly burnt tarts on the pans. Disappointed but predicted it would happen. Initially I was going to get 2-3 tarts but by the time I moved up order, I changed my mind. Ordered 6 tarts for $21 + tax. #DentInMyWallet I waited in line for 35+ mins after work...I was gonna treat myself dammit! The people in front of me ordered 1 tart and in my head I was like...damn y'all waited half an hour for one tart o__O so wow, much patience.

My 6 pack was boxed up and bagged, and I was on my way...upstairs to get glamour shots of the tarts and of the dome. I didn't try them until 4 hours later bc I had to commute back to my town and go to the gym. Gotta lose some calories before packing them back on amiright?! I popped one in the microwave for 10 secs and went in for the first bite. Wow. Speechless. The tart was light and subtle cheese flavor with a splash of sweetness. It was creamy and fluffy, too. Definitely something I've never had before. And that crust...DAMN. It really balanced the creamy fluffiness. #GoodTexture I wanted to eat all 6 but I didn't want to be a fatass that night. They were to share amongst fam and friends lol. But yeah, it was pretty darn good. 

Overall, it's a good tart-- cheesy, fluffy, slightly crunchy and not to sweet. I agree with the other peeps that they are expensive and the wait time is ridank. They should definitely add in another cashier. Hopefully after things settle down, the work flow will be more efficient and the line will move faster. I'll be back in a few months. Tryna get my hands on a chocolate tart!
author: Vicky L.

description:
TASTY...if you survive the wait. Unless you are traveling from afar to get these Tarts, come when the line is less than 15 min.

The little shop/stand is pretty small, neat, and straightforward. In the food court, you won't miss their wall stacked with the yellow packaging.

The tarts themselves are delicious. If you want to get the chocolate ones, you have to come earlier in the day (they sell out by noontime, the manager told me). They are strict on quantities that they bake each day (because they are shipped in to be heated). I was relieved to find that the crust wasn't too overwhelming! The light, cheese filling sticks to your teeth then melts in your mouth. It's like you're biting into a cloud.
author: Janelle W.

description:
When this place first showed up at the mall, I had no idea what it was. A little research later, I put it on my list to try, but it wasn't top priority because of mixed reviews. After a lazy Sunday spent wandering downtown, I had some time to kill before catching a movie at the Metreon. I wasn't hungry enough for dinner, so a snack seemed like a perfect medium.

The line was around the corner when I joined, stretching about 20-25 people long. Unfortunately, they have a very inefficient set up (or possibly just strategic on their part?) and they only have one register. They have two flavors: original and their seasonal flavor, which happened to be matcha. After some internal deliberations, I decided on the matcha.

For $3.91 (incl tax), I was given one matcha cheese tart and a napkin. I'll admit, it was pretty good. People say there's a strong matcha flavor, and I don't think it was especially strong, but strong enough to know it was matcha flavored. The crust was thick, but had a good buttery flavor to it and snapped with each bite, without flaking and falling apart all over the place. The filling was soft inside and oozed out a bit with my initial bite.

Like others said before me, it's good, just not life-altering good. I think trying it once suffices because the $3.91 price tag is a bit pricey for what you get.
author: Leana L.

description:
Wanted to try these while I was in HK recently but didn't get a chance. Luckily when I came back I found out this store just opened here in the states. 

Downstairs in the food court area inside SF Centre
Came after work and the line was long but waitable. Maybe 15-20min.

Picked up 3 tarts and ate one on the spot. Smell was too enticing. Very yummy but kinda small for $3.50 a pop.
author: Linda W.

description: This concept is really weird. I had the matcha and custard. Custard is the more natural combination. Not sure I like this concept. To be fair, the matcha tasted very matcha so they got that done really well. And the crust was done well too.
author: Rose F.

description:
As you may have expected, they sell cheese tarts.  They are $3.65 a piece.  They are a bit pricey because it's their first and only location in the US.  It tastes like cheesecake with a harder crust.  

Service: The customer service is TERRIBLE.  You are limited with your purchase and they will tell you to wait in line if you want to buy more.  I know your job sucks, but the least you can say is hello with a smile and end your order with thank you.  

Food: The crust is hard with fluffy cheese on top.  I've tried the original and matcha.  As for the matcha, you don't really taste much of it.  It does taste a little bitter because they burned the top.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
So yummy - I'm not really sure where you can find a cheese tart like this anywhere else! I tried this on a whim when in Japan so I knew that the quality would be up to par here and (although it's hard to compare/remember), I believe it is! But it is pretty expensive for what you get and I like to treat myself to one every once in a while but can't really get myself to bring a box home. I usually just grab one and eat it immediately.

The times I've been, I haven't seen any special flavors. One thing is that the browning on top is a bit inconsistent on the tarts. It's definitely worth trying once especially because the line isn't bad anymore.
author: Erika N.

description: I love their cheese tarts! My kids are addicted to these too they would eat a bunch in one sitting. They're a bit pricey but I think it's worth it! The calories are worth it too!
author: Ly L.

description:
There was a ton of hype for this place over the weekend, so I hoped to jump on the bandwagon since I was in the area.  I arrived to the mall before 10 am and went straight to the food court as the doors opened.  Luckily, a crowd hadn't formed yet and I was the 4th person in line.  A few minutes passed and the next thing I knew, there was another 30 people in line behind me.  I only ordered a couple tarts after seeing the person in front of me shell out $40 just for a dozen.   

Taking my first bite, I was expecting to taste an egg tart.  But, I was very wrong.  The crust was crispy similar to the egg tart, but the filling was a lot softer and creamier. It reminded me of cheese cake.  The chocolate tart was not too sweet and had a slightly salty taste.  I was not as impressed since I am not a huge chocolate person.  

Overall, I was very impressed by the taste and quality of the tarts.  The service was a bit lacking as they could only serve one person at a time and they seem to still be figuring out logistics.  If it wasn't for the steep price, I would come back often.  But for now, I will have to save these for special occasions.
author: Mitch T.

description:
This is a Japanese chain that opened its very first store in the US! It's located in the basement of the Westfield mall, right next to the mall exit to BART/Muni.

The cheese tart itself is delicious-- golden brown on the outside with a rich savory-sweet filling in the center. The filling is some sort of cream cheese, kind of like a softer cheesecake in a tart form.

The taste was great, but I can't recommend it based on its price alone. $3.50 each is a bit too much for my taste, but it's definitely worth a try once (or maybe twice) as a small dessert.
author: Tien L.

description:
Flavor Ranking, if you get a chance to try em:

Strawberry 
Original
Green tea
author: Jessica C.

description: Great tarts in Westfield! My sister got 6 original tarts for me and my family to try. I decided to try the tarts at room temperature and after I heated them up in a toaster oven. The room temp tarts were great, the filling was creamy and the crust had just enough sweetness to complement the filling. When baked, the filling becomes all gooey and the flavors tasted the same. I wish they had other flavors, but my sister told me all they had were the original flavors. I definitely want to come back and try the different flavors!
author: Lisa C.

description:
These cheese tarts were AMAZING!!! When we first saw the prices it was pretty steep but we still bought 6 pieces and enjoyed them in all the different ways they provided on a slip of paper. My favorite way of eating them was warm and freshly toasted but eating it refrigerated was delicious in its own way. If you love cheesecake, I recommend eating it cold!

Compared to 85c's cheese tarts, I feel like these ones are fluffier and the pie crust is crunchier and doesn't fall apart. I definitely recommend everyone to try these!
author: Joelle P.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Bake but this first US location sure gives the entire company a horrible name.  All the workers always look so miserable working here, no one is ever happy or smiling and after my encounter with their manager, Leah, today...I can see why.  She can care less about her customers, let alone her workers.  That's such a shame since these tarts are always so tasty and reminds me of my vacations in Japan.

I always make sure to get my cheese tart fix whenever I'm in Japan and Bake has definitely created a name for themselves in Asia.  Warm, fluffy cheese tarts oozing with sweetness but what sets them apart is their nice packaging and friendly service but this SF location is anything but that.  :(

Case in point, today is their first day of launching their seasonal strawberry cheese tarts that has also been shipped over from Japan (nothing is made fresh onsite btw...all shipped frozen from Japan and just baked here).  Customers such as myself have waited patiently weeks for its arrival so it's no surprise we were all excited.  I got to Westfield at 1:30pm this afternoon and was told a new batch of strawberry tarts will be coming out at 2pm.  If you have been here, you will know that there is always a line, sometimes fast but sometimes painfully slooooooow.  Since there was already a line, I proceeded to stand in it not knowing how long wait time will be but to my surprise today, I got to the front of the line by 1:45pm.  Trays and trays of their strawberry cheese tarts were all ready to go, cooled enough that the strawberry toppings were already placed on them.  Since I did not expect to get to the front of the line so quick today, I kindly asked the cashier if I can pay for the tarts first, I will gladly wait to 2pm when they bring them out.  I was appalled when she shouted at me and said "No!  they are not coming out until 2pm."  I understand that and I am more than happy to stand aside and not disrupt the flow of their line but to my surprised, she said I needed to stand back in that long line and wait again.  Hopefully, the next time I'm back up to the front, it will be after 2pm already.  WTF?!?  That makes no sense, why couldn't they just make a separate line for those just waiting for the strawberry tarts rather than making people stand back in line over and over again in hopes to "time" it right?!? 

Leah, the manager walked up and I explained to her nicely that I understand that the tarts won't start selling until 2pm but other customers, along with myself, did not know how long the line was going to take so we all stood here waiting for the strawberry tarts.  She too said no, that we all have to stand back in line and firmly said "it's first come, first serve....you can get it if you are the first customers in line by 2pm".  Clearly, that won't happen anymore since by then, I was only 10 minutes shy from 2pm and the line was growing.  I understand rules are rules but man, talk about no customer service at all.  As a manager, she could have taken control of the situation and started a new line or kindly understand that we are literally minutes away from her 2pm batch but yeah, that was not the case.  Leah could have care less if we wait in that line again and not get any strawberry tarts.  Her cold attitude towards her customers is a big reflection of how her employees reacts too which just makes it a nasty vicious cycle.  

Seriously, I was ready to leave for being treated so poorly...I really wished I was not such a big sucker for sweets and that I didn't promise my family that I will bring some to dinner tonight.  Thankfully, I ran into my cousin and since we were chatting, I was encouraged to wait in that line again, blah!  The tarts are without a doubt tasty but the poor service that comes along with the price tag, I will much rather wait until the next time I'm in Japan or Asia to have them again.  Bake SF - shame on you!

Kudos to the girls that were a few down the line from me and did not take their BS!!  They created their own strawberry line and firmly stood there, telling customers to go ahead of them who just wanted to buy the original tarts.  You go girls!!
author: Janetto L.

description:
This small shop is located in the food court of the Westfield mall in San Francisco. This place only sells Cheese Tarts, so I got a Cheese Tart. It is pretty expensive for one, $3.50. I came at 11am so there was no line.

Cheese Tart- Very expected. The texture is amazing. It was like something I have never eaten before. The crust was crunchy and broke off easily as I bit it, but the filling was creamy in a light way. It was sooo good. The taste was kind of like a cheesecake. Besides the price of it, it was something I would definitely eat again. 

Overall, I absolutely would eat this again.
author: Felicia C.

description: These cheese tarts are tasty, like the filling of a danish, but I wouldn't say they are worth the hefty price of $3.50 each or the long wait. Beard papas are just as tasty and no line.
author: Tu-Quyen P.

description:
Cheese tarts yumm. $3.50 is a hefty price for one of these small tarts but hey it's a specialty tart so I guess I could hand over my money. I really liked the crust. It was still crunchy even the next day with a simple reheat. The cheese is melty and pretty sweet. It's like a Portuguese tart. I definitely would eat again, but prob won't pay again. 

The line wrapped around to the sliding doors was about a 30 min wait. IDK why it takes so long. You only have ONE THING to choose from. You just tell the person how many and they will grab it before you even reach the register. Seems like such a fast process but geez, it takes a lifetime to get up front. Oh, if you don't want the overly brown ones, you can request it and they will give you the less brown ones.
author: Benita M.

description:
Every time I pass by this place, there's always a line so I try to go when I see the line isn't as long. 

First time I went there, all their other flavors were all sold out so I had to get the original. The original was good. The cheese consistency was so light and fluffy. Since my tart was a little warmish, it tasted better than if it was in room temperature. I gave my mom the tart as a to go when it was room temperature and she was underwhelmed by it.

My second time coming here I saw they had a limited time matcha flavor tart and me being a huge matcha lover, I had to try it out. The matcha tart tasted better than the original in my opinion. It wasn't overly sweet nor was it too bitter as well. 

Overall, I think the prices of the tarts are pretty pricey in my opinion. I wouldn't come here again just for another original or matcha tart but if they had any other interesting or limited time flavors, I would probably try it out.
author: Kochamon S.

description: I came on a Saturday morning, at 11am, and there was little to no line. If there were people, the line moved fast. They do have a limit of how many you can purchase per person. I got the original cheese tart and being a cheesecake lover, I loved this cheese tart. I'm actually not a fan of overly rich cheesecake so I think I prefer cheese tarts now, if I need to satisfy a personal cheese craving. The tart is fluffy and caramelized beautifully on the top. The crust is buttery and flaky so it is not overwhelmingly heavy at all. I think i consumed the whole tart in two bites. So good!! A must stop by if you are in the Westfield San Francisco center!
author: Alice W.

description:
A teammate gets these almost every Friday and shares them with the team and I gotta say, they are amazing.

A bit too heavy if you're not hungry, so it's always nice to split them in half.
author: Antonio H.

description:
Hopefully by now everyone at the Powell Bart station might or might not have figured out how to get around the huge line out the door from BCT because it is long. but do not let that stop you because it is 100% worth the wait. 
To keep this short - two flavors - cheese and chocolate and I would go after lunch rush hour or super early in the morning otherwise expect at least a 20-30 min wait line. 1 cash register person who is super friendly as well as the staff. towards the end of the day they do run out so its whatever the production batch is. The tarts themselves melt in your mouth and the taste is pretty awesome. Pricy AF for them because one of them is $3.50 but hey when something like this blows up and 1/2 the SF population is blowing up IG and yelp with reviews you pay the price. All in all this was an awesome addition to the mid-market desert options!
author: Ankita C.

description: If you love cheese cake, you MUST try the cheese tart. There is usually a line and I personally don't like waiting, but I think cheese tarts are worth the wait if you never tried them. The tarts melt in your mouth, and the filling is super fluffy and it's perfect with the crust. Always get more than 1 because they disappear in your mouth. They also various seasonal flavors-- I've tried the green tea tart, and it wasn't as good as the original cheese tart. The green tea tart had super strong green tea flavor, but I definitely prefer cheese better.
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description: Underated! I remember seeing a video on FB, and I wanted to try this. They were sold out of the Seasonal Strawberry Cheese Tart, but the regular one was yummy! The crust tasted like a sugar cookie without all the sugar coating and slightly less sweet. Meanwhile, the middle was like a cloudy, fluffy cheesecake that taste like marshmellow fluff. The crispy crust with the gooey and cheesy contrast made it fun to eat. I prefer this over traditional Chinese Egg Tart. It was just a bit warm right out of the box, and if you get a box of 6 like me, make sure to take home the reheating instructions. It was certainly fun to eat, and I will be returning soon to try the Strawberry one.
author: Sarah T.

description:
(Sing in a raspy old man voice)

A one, anda two, anda one, two, three!
Hatcha hatcha hatcha!
Love your matcha matcha!
Don't want a line?
Show up on time.
Like a little sweet?
Enough to move your feet?
Hatcha hatcha hatcha!
Then chomp to the beat!

These matcha cheesecakes are perfection.  Do you pay for perfection? I did, and will again.  I hadn't read the Yelp reviews so was unaware of the line problem as I sauntered right up to the register on a Monday around noon.  We bought a 6 pack (sure to destroy anyone's 6 pack) and shared it with work colleagues.  I'll definitely stop here any time I'm at Westfield.  Beard Papa, move over.  (Though I still love you dearly too...)

Hatcha hatcha hatcha!
author: Ravena F.

description: So happy that bake cheese tart opened a location in SF! It tastes just like the one I had in Japan! The lines are definitely not as long as when it first opened! I went twice so far and only waited maybe 10-15min max. I tried the matcha one recently but honestly like the original one a lot more! Hoping to try more flavors though!
author: ashley z.

description: The reviews are so mixed and I couldn't figure out if it was worth it to get in the line. Being a big foodie I knew if I didn't try it was going to bother me forever. There was about 20-25 people in line but line moves quick. I bought 6 originals which were 6 for $20. I thought they were pretty good. They are like a super fluffy cheese cake. If you love cheese cake you will love these little tarts. I had 4 left over in the fridge from the day before but they weren't as good the next day but still not bad. Soooo if you get them eat them the same day.
author: Sam P.

description: Delicious Jap cheese tarts with original flavor and a seasonal flavor. Oh, and NO LINE if you go on weekdays.
author: Betty T.

description:
I was so excited when my friend told me about this place and how great their tarts are. Came here twice now, both on weekends and neither time had to wait more than 10 minutes to get my tarts. There is usually a line but it moves forward pretty fast. It's located across from the Walgreen on the corner of the Bart exit on the food court floor. 

As for the taste, I'm a fan. The inside is really cheesy while the crust is crunchy. It is sooo good after a day of walking around in the mall. The downside is I really wish they have more flavors than just the plain cheese tart. I guess they have the strawberry flavors now but seems to run out really fast (didn't have the luck to try them yet). 

Would come again next time I'm in town and would recommend to someone with a sweet tooth and who enjoys tarts.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I came in a little after a month it had opened, I was fairly skeptical walking over because I wasn't sure if the hype had died down or not, thank god it did. 

Came in around 1:30 in the afternoon on a Sunday and the line was fairly short, I was hoping they would still have their chocolate tarts but unfortunately not just their original but it looks like they will be coming out with a strawberry one soon. 

I was able to purchase a dozen which came out to like $40 something which is a bit crazy for these things. I mean they're good but not THAT mind blowing. Definitely a good little dessert if you were craving something lightly sweetened.

The crust is definitely flakey and sweet & as for the cheese part is like a fluffy yet creamy cheesecake. 

They have some toppings you can add on over to the side of their register: chocolate powder, caramel & another one which I forgot. I opted out of adding any but I'm sure they would've made just as scrumptious.
author: Rheanna V.

description:
It is a very expensive tart - $3.45 for a little tart and they have two flavors - original and green tea. There is a limit of 6 green tea per person, but I don't think that will be a problem at their prices. 

While I don't think they are worth their prices, the tarts are quite good. The cream cheese is soft and custard-like. The green tea flavor is very strong and I would not recommend it unless you like matcha green tea. The crust is very hard like a cookie - probably to hold up the very creamy cheese - but I prefer my tart crust to be flakier.
author: July N.

description:
Really something different and special. I say this because no where else sells this (in california), that i know. 

Its like eating baked, sweet, cream cheese on a durable, not rock hard, crust. 

I must say lines are long as trains on weekends (1-1.5 hours wait), when we first got them when they opened. Hopefully the hype died down for you when you go. On the weekdays its was like 5 mins dude.
author: Kun L.

description: You want a few bites of heaven? Treat yourself here!!! Located inside Westfield, this hidden gem will satisfy a naughty craving and you don't feel guilty afterwards. I got an assorted box of their seasonal strawberry tart and their original. Both amazing! Extremely fluffy and creamy at the same time! They sell out early evening and have long lines around lunch so I would highly suggest going when they open at 10am. Fantastic customer service as well!
author: Sahar N.

description:
Glad the hype for this place finally slowed down. The first time I passed by the Powell location the line wrapped around the corner. This time around the line was only 1 person long - needless to say, now's the time to come check out this dessert shop. 

Heads up before you come - chocolate is no longer in season. The season's option is strawberry cheese tart.

They give you a box if you order 6+ ($21). Otherwise, each tart is $3.50 and they put it in a bag that they can seal for you. I do think the price is  a little steep for something you can eat in 3 bites, but it's worth a try. 

Bake Cheese Tart's filling reminds me of Cheesecake factory options just more creamy/melt in your mouth. The filling pairs well with the crust which is more of a solid vs. flaky texture. I like that they brulee the top of the tart which adds an additional texture to each bite. 

Overall, I thought it was tasty and am willing to come back to try their other flavors, but it might not be my first option when I'm craving something sweet because these tarts are not the cheapest go-to option.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Friend brought these cheese tarts to book club. They were very attractively packaged in a yellow paper container (so Japanese) and very tasted. They are something between a dim sum egg tart and a cheese cake. I wouldn't say that they blew my mind away, but they are a unique treat.
author: Julia C.

description:
Cheese tarts are a big hit in Japan, and Bake is one of the well known chains selling these delicious petite tarts. Bake recently opened a branch right in downtown SF, and the hype was real with the long line stretching towards the entrance to the BART station.

After a few months when the lines died down, I finally got the chance to purchase a few towards closing time. I ordered a box of 6 to bring home to share with my family, and left it in the fridge until the next day. The cheese tart became quite firm, just like a typical American cheesecake. The flavor was good -- quite creamy and rich, and the pastry itself provided a contrasting texture to the cream. I think I probably would have preferred it eaten before refrigerating, so the cream is more smoother.

For $3.50 a tart of $20 for 6, it's very expensive for what you get -- almost double the price you would find in Tokyo. Probably won't come back again and just wait until I visit Japan again.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Omg was so excited they opened in the US that we had to come here when we were in town. Surprisingly, the wait was only about 5 min. We ordered three to share and that came in a bag. You get a box with orders of 6!
It was almost as good as it was in Japan ! Still delicious and love the Japanese butter cookie crust.
author: Audrey C.

description:
I had no idea this place existed or was such a big deal! While walking back towards the BART station, I saw pics of what looked like fancy Portuguese Egg Tarts and a small crowd - enough to sucker a lemming like me to also jump in line!

Long story short: these mini Japanese cheesecake tarts are tasty! As with most Asian desserts, they're less sweet and dense compared to American desserts. These also have a nice butter cookie crust.

But come on, $3.50 each is highway robbery!
author: Steve L.

description: Love the original cheese tart! The seasonal flavor is strawberry right now, starting from July 6th. Not a fan of it.
author: Claire Y.

description:
I came here in the late afternoon a few weeks after their grand opening. There was a line that led out to the Muni/Bart station, but the line went pretty quickly. Looking at the workers putting and bringing out the cheese tarts out of the oven was fascinating. It was a good way to waste time while in line. 
I bought half a dozen to share with my family and baked them again in the oven when I got home cause they got cold. It was sweet, savory, hot and crispy! The cheese tart tasted more like melted cream cheese than a cheesecake to me.
author: Christine Y.

description: If the line is short, it's worth! The tart is so good. It's like a dan tat but the inside is cheesecake. The crust isn't flakey, but has a nice crunch. The filling is pretty rich, but not to the point that I want to throw up. It's lighter than an actual cheesecake, but not like whipped cream frosting. It's worth $3.50 for cheesecake fans!
author: Caitlyn S.

description: I finally got to try this place which had been opened for a couple months now and the hype has finally died! I was EXTREMELY disappointed in this tart. In no way is it worth what was charged and did not blow my mind. The tart was barely even warm, the texture of the tart was very mushy & kind of liquidy , the taste was super flat, and the crust was pretty firm and hard.
author: Chi L.

description:
Why would anyone want to buy a friging double sided cheezy ritz cracker. Like come on I can make this at my house with some chonies as a blindfold. It's ridiculous, I tried taking my youngest son, one in profile picture, to this place and he liked it. So I gave him a spanking every night for a week. If I were you, I would go down to your nearest target and buy some ritz crackers and a fat block of cheddar cheese.
because that is exactly how it tastes. And don't even get me started on the constant bum aches, my bum was aching all morning. That actually might of been from the rental car place, but still. I'm pretty sure I smelt an extra 2 or 3 chromosomes in there. Not a fun place experience. I would rather have 10 people slap me on the tush then eat one of these ritz cracker wannabes.
author: Dequavus G.

description: I was conveniently at the mall around 8pm and came upon this place. I've heard so much hype about this place and how amazingly long the line is usually, so when I saw the line was short, I knew I had to take this chance to try it out! I stood in line for about 10 minutes. They have a system where they would give you small cards to represent how many tarts you will plan to buy. I bought 6 original for $21. They look cute but to be honest, I didn't think it was anything to write home about. The outer is a crunchy buttery cookie dough crust and the inner filling is a slightly fluffier cheese cake. Just imagine both of these together and you get their famous baked cheese tart. When I gave it a try, I was rather disappointed. I thought the cheese would ooze out and be amazing, but turns out it was just okay. Maybe I need to reheat it?
author: Hoyan L.

description:
As good as I remember from Japan!! 

I had this in Tokyo when I went in the summer of 2017. The temperature and the textures were SO good. It doesn't sound positive when I write it, but trust me, it's a good thing. The temperature is almost hot and the texture is almost runny. Not only is the temperature and texture of the custard perfect, the crust is like a crispy short bread. It's the perfect vessel to hold the delicious cheese.

Cheese in Asia is completely different compared to European and American. It's is more tart than a New York cheese cake and much more light. If you like any of the creama concepts on drinks, you'll like this. 

Anticipate a long wait because there is one. I've seen it wrap all the way around and go into the transit station. There is also a limit you can purchase. 

For all my cheese tart lovers, this one is the best. I bid you patience in line.
author: Tina Y.

description:
I didn't try this cheese tart brand while I was in Japan so I can't compare. I personally think the cheese tarts are good! So did everyone else I gave it to. I bought the 6 pack and it came in a neat box. I had one the same day I bought it and one the next day after leaving it in the fridge.

I got in line on a Wednesday at 3pm and waited for about 5 minutes, not too long of a wait. Personally, I think the people behind the counter could work a little more efficiently. Would the line move faster if some boxes of 6 were pre-packed and ready to go if you're only selling one flavor? ‍
author: Stephanie L.

description: They tastes good but it's expensive. $3.5 for single piece is too much given the small size. It's okay for one time taste but definitely not going to buy again. There's a line in weekend but weekdays noon or afternoons are great timings to go.
author: Maulik S.

description:
Soft gooey center that was silky smooth and slightly sweet with a tangy tartness. Crust is a cookie crust that was kind of hard and thick. Too much crust to cheese ratio. And as other noted, the finish on the tarts in a single tray are inconsistent and uneven. They should invest in a better oven system to heat up their assembly line of frozen tarts.

People line moves quick! Pricey at $3.50 ea.

Chocolate flavor sold out for the rest of the season though they have strawberry soon.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Modern twist on egg tarts!

Although pretty pricey ($3.50) the cheese tart was sweet on the outside and savory and creamy on the inside. The crust was hard, (in a good way) unlike the usual flaky egg tart crusts.
author: Megan L.

description:
What they got right:
- first US branch
- good marketing
- clever packaging
- tasty cheese tart

Areas for improvement:
- speed of getting orders ready
- speed of baking cheese tart
- more efficiency

This review was based on opening day, May 4, so there may been be some changes since. 

I got there at 9:30am and waited in line for 2.5 hours till they opened at 12 noon. Even after they officially opened at 12 noon, it took another hour for me to put in my order. There were 12-15 people in front of me. If there was one area to order and another area for pick-up, it might have gone faster. There were a lot of staff standing around trying to be "busy".

When I finally got my tarts, I noticed there were inconsistencies of the tart tops ... some were noticeably burnt.

The tarts were sweet & sour, like cream cheese. The crust was good and flakey but I've had better. 

Were they worth the 3.5 hour wait? No. It was neat to be one of the first to try these famous tarts from Japan. I would buy them for friends but I probably wouldn't buy them for myself.

The packaging was awesome and deserves its own star rating. The boxes keep the individual tarts safe from crushing the others.
author: Kimi K.

description:
Luckily we hit this place on a Wednesday afternoon about 2:15 and line was nice and short maybe eight people ahead of us. Was able to pick up a dozen and had a few that that evening and they were delicious. Just put them in the toaster oven and heat them up low and slow and get a nice warm light cheesecake type of tart. Yes it's pricey so it's a treat. 

We've put some in the freezer for later consumption before and heating in toaster oven brings it up to another level. Haven't tried it cold yet. Just don't heat so it's too runny inside.
author: Laine G.

description:
Unbelievable!

So incredibly delightful!

The crust is almost shortbread like - firm, thick and buttery -- it's the perfect vehicle to transport the deliciously gooey cheesecake filling!

And the top of this 6 bite tarte is brûléed.

Their partnership with dandelion for the chocolate tarte is genius and limited so get em while they're available.

$3.75 each and worth every bite!
#addicted!
author: Charlie B.

description:
Lines are starting to die down finally. 
Was so excited to try these since I kept seeing people carrying the cute bright yellow bags! 
Price wise, a bit high for one small lil tart at $3.50 each. And trust me you don't just buy ONE. 
Taste wise, it's delicious. It's not as fluffy as the Japanese jiggly cheesecakes but it's way less dense than your typical slice of NY cheesecake. The texture is perfect as it doesn't feel heavy after you eat it. It's still creamy yet light. 
Be careful and don't be like me and eat quite a few at one sitting!!
author: Connie Y.

description:
Soooooo GOOD!!!! Fluffy & creamy filling it's amazing totally worth the wait :) 

Although it is kind of pricey
author: Apple P.

description:
I remember when I would always pass this bake cheese tart place in a Japan subway station and there was always a line there. One day, I eventually sucked it up and waited in line. They were warm, delicious, and the perfect amount of sweetness. Needless to say, when I brought them back to share with family, by the next morning, the whole entire box was gone.

When Bake Cheese Tart announced that they would be opening up a store here in SF, I was super excited. I could finally get my dad a cheese tart.

I went on a Wednesday after work around 5pm allocating myself about 45 minutes to get a box before my dinner reservation. The line wrapped around the corner ending just at the door between the mall and BART. The dinner moved relatively fast and about 25 minutes later, I had purchased a box. They were a bit warm and tasted exactly like the ones I had in Japan, except they were a little more burnt. These aren't super sweet so you can eat many in one seating. You can either eat them fresh or refrigerate them for a firmer texture. Le bf who had never had them before wasn't really sold on them. He would rate them 3 stars. He wasn't a big fan of the crust, which was more like a cookie. My dad, who is a cheesecake fan, enjoyed his warm. But after hearing how much I paid per tart, he enjoyed them a bit less. 

With the lines being so long, the cheese tarts being more expensive than the ones I purchased in Japan and them running out of the chocolate ones (there was a sign saying they sold out), I don't think I'll be back anytime soon. But it is nice to know that there is a cheese tart place should I ever crave them.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Every morning, I see a line coming from this new store that goes out into the Powell BART station. The doors into the mall from the station open at 10am and there's ALREADY a line! It also makes the mall smell really good. So I just had to try one today. There were only about 5 people in line just before noon. It probably took about 5-10 minutes from the end of the window.

Honestly, the line moves pretty slowly when all they have to do is bag the little tarts and ring up the customer. You can't even order more than a certain number of tarts! So I don't really understand why the line moves so slowly. There were 4 workers! One at the cash register, one bagging the tarts, one switching out the trays of tarts, and another who disappeared into the back for a little bit. It could be way faster if one of the employees was outside, taking down orders.

BUT my confusion was melted as soon as I bit into my first cheese tart. It was like the world's softest cheesecake in tart-form, but not tart/sour. The pastry crust was surprisingly firm. It was room temperature. And it was just big enough to get a few bites out of it before it was gone.

I would say it's worth $3.50, especially since it's shipped from Japan, but probably NOT worth an hour wait (like some other Yelpers have mentioned). You can't get more than 12 original cheese tarts, but I don't even think you need 6, unless you're sharing with 3-6 people.

But I REALLY wanna try the chocolate one now, but one of the employees said they won't be getting anymore chocolate ones until summer 2019! I saw a sign for strawberry flavor, so expect another round of cheese tart hype very soon!

PS - they also have a self-serve toppings corner on the side. They had caramel sauce, cocoa powder, and cinnamon powder.
author: Athena C.

description:
I bought a box of 6 to take home. I thought the crust was good. It was flaky and very buttery. The cheese tart filling taste was too cheesy for me.  It was a bit tangy, which I found odd. The texture of the filling was light.

Eating the remaining tarts cold is a different story. I found the tart filling taste to be more intensified. Sometimes eating something cold is not the best thing.  I am happy to have tried this, but I don't think I will buy again.
author: Marck N.

description:
I really love egg tarts so when the cheese tarts opened up, I was all over it. The location is inside the mall so that makes it a bit awkward but the line is always wrapping around the corner

Composition: egg tarts are firm in the middle and have softer shells, cheese tarts are soft in the middle and have firmer shells. This is the main reason why I like them so much, I'm a firm believer that a crust is just as important as the filling. You can tell that the cream cheese filling was lapped in with egg whites, because of its fluffiness

Taste: the filling of the cheese tart is noticeably cream cheese (similar to a cheesecake) with a sprinkle of salt on top. When you first bite into it, you taste the saltiness but I don't think they mix it into the filling because I personally dissected the filling - it was sweet and creamy. So if you're thrown off by it at first, just know it's meant to compliment, not shock you.

Pricing: Would I pay $3.50 for a cheese tart? Yes. Would I pay another $3.50 for a cheese tart? Yes. Let me make the decision easy for you - BUY 6.
author: Angella G.

description:
I was so happy to see that first North American Bake Cheese Tart was in SF! I first tried it during my trips back to Hong Kong, so it's definitely a treat to have it more accessible now.

This branch is located in the SF Westfield Mall food court and is hard to miss. I went around 6:30pm on a Tuesday and only stood in line for about 5 minutes. I ordered 6 original and 6 matcha flavored tarts. 

Taste: 5/5 - Lovely taste and texture. Fluffy filling and a crumbled butter crust is the perfect combination! The original is still my favorite, but it was nice to try the matcha one. The matcha flavor really came through without compromising the texture of the cheesecake.

Price: 3/5 - This is definitely not something you would buy on the regular because it is pricey. I would come here on occasion for a special treat or if I'm craving their cheese tarts. Like others have mentioned, the best deal is to buy 6 original cheese tarts for $20 rather than individually. The matcha ones don't have a special price if you buy 6.
author: Lindsay K.

description: I'm not gonna lie, it's like eating cheesecake in a cupcake form with a crust. It's so fluffy, creamy, and flavorful. But for $3.50 and waiting in line, I'd rather eat an actual cheesecake. Worth a try though.
author: Debbie D.

description:
it's pretty pricey ($3.50 each or six for $21) but very tasty. think of all the good things about egg tarts and all the good things about cheesecake and combine them together and you get a cheese tart 

from what i've heard, the line for this place is usually pretty crazy, but when we went on memorial day, it wasn't too bad (10-15 min wait)
author: David K.

description:
Came at 6pm tonight and waited for only about 10 minutes! The hype has definitely died down in the last few weeks! 

Was happy about that ... but then something totally killed my experience and left a very bitter taste in my mouth. 

About 5 minutes upon waiting in line, a lady with a clipboard came around and asked us how many tarts we wanted to order. We told her our numbers and she then proceeded to give us a small tag with the designated # of tarts we had said we planned on ordering. Mind you, there's already a limit of tarts each person can purchase. 

When we get to the front of the line, my friend decides that she wants to add 2 more. The cashier doesn't allow us to saying something like they only baked enough for how many people ordered in line. 

i call BULL$hit. Your tarts come frozen in a box. You put them in your Combi-oven and bake them for less than 10 minutes, and you tell me there's limited quantity? We just gave the lady with the clipboard our numbers FIVE minutes ago. You have got to be kidding! Unless you cut the line off already, you're going to be making more egg tarts until you close. I wasn't born yesterday to know that;  you douchebag of a cashier working on a Sunday 5/20 at 6:00pm. Talk about shoddy customer service. It's not like we wanted to add A LOT more cheese tarts. Only 2 more. TWO TARTS to the TWO that we originally ordered making it a grand total of FOUR. You're going to be stingy and make a bunch of lame rules . Where are your signs buddy? Whatever. High prices are one thing, but a blatant lack of respect for your customers is another. I'm never coming back. 

On to the cheese tart. It's just MEH. Instagram worthy with all those tarts sitting on trays gleaming under the storefront lights--But upon biting into one, it reminded me of a sweeter Ritz crackers cheese, with a smooth creamy aftertaste. I put it in the fridge to see if the taste and texture will be better tomorrow. I hope so! For $3.50 a pop, Im definitely not coming back and letting  everyone that I know that they have a bunch of bogus ordering "rules" and need to check themselves before they wreck themselves.
author: Kay H.

description: Got lucky and only lined up for 5-10 minutes today (came around 2pm on a Monday). I got one chocolate and one cheese flavor for $3.50 each. Both were super creamy and the crust had a great texture to it. I'd probably get this again if the line was short.
author: Victoria T.

description:
Really not worth the hype, but worth the try for a one-time experience.

I came here right after seeing trending videos of this location on social media. I'm a big foodie and right when I heard that this is the first location opening up in the USA from Japan, I wanted to try the cheese tarts immediately.

Came here after work (Thursday around 5pm) and the line looked pretty long; however, it moved fairly quickly. When we came they had a limited edition flavor: Strawberry Cheese Tart. 

We ordered a box of six with a mix of both the original cheese tart and the strawberry one. We were really surprised by how expensive they came out to be. You're paying $4 for literally two bites. 

I honestly prefer regular egg tarts over these cheese tarts. They're much cheaper and tastier!

I also heard from somewhere that this location doesn't make the cheese tarts fresh. They're actually made in Japan and they just heat them up here, so they won't be as great as having them fresh from the original location.
author: Pariya N.

description:
Wow -- delicious, fluffy, and mouthwatering.

These Japanese cheese tarts are absolutely heavenly! The crisp cookie shell is light and buttery, filled with a creamy sweet cheese mousse. Almost comparable to a hybrid mini cheese cake and an egg custard. I inhaled four cheese tarts within 5 minutes. Yes, they are really that good!

$26.58 for half a dozen delectable cheese tarts and a small Brazilian coffee. Shall I say, a-m-a-z-i-n-g?
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
TL;DR - good fluffy, runny, crispy cheese tarts when hot. Same as the one sold in Japan. Buy one. 

I think the line hype died, which is good. Waited 15 mins or so on Friday night. 

It tastes the same as the one from their Japan stores. Though it costs more here unfortunately, the price of SF ($3.25 each vs less than $2 overseas)

Texture of the cheese tart, if it is hot still, melts and run, but crispy pie crust. If it is cooler, then the cheese is more solidified. I like it a lot when it is still warm. I recommend using a turbo/convection oven to heat it up. 

They even give you authentic Japanese napkins, which is more of a wax paper texture than paper. Would go back at times if it wasn't so far. I hope they bring a branch to LA/SoCal area.
author: Chris T.

description:
Came here on a weekday around 6:30pm and only waited for less than 10 minutes.

By the time I arrived, they already ran out of the chocolate flavor so definitely need to go back and try those. The cheese filling has a super light texture and is almost like liquid or whip cream, but I would recommend chilling in the fridge for a while before eating if you like a more solid texture. It tasted way better after!

A bit expensive (almost ($4 per cheese tart) but pretty good. Just don't expect it to be like an asian egg tart and refrigerate before eating!
author: Angela P.

description: NBA Finals were on so I knew there wouldn't be a crazy line and boy was it worth it. Never had these before so I bought 6 and literally could not get enough. They're like little bites of heaven. Would totally wait in line for them again but wish it moved faster!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My friend and I were in the area, and she had heard about this place, especially just coming back from a trip from Japan she wanted to try it. The line was pretty long since it had just opened 2 weeks prior, but moved semi quickly since there was not much to choose from. They ran out of the chocolate tart, so they only had original and they limit you on how much you can buy. I am really not a HUGE fan or cheese pastries, etc but since I stood in line I thought might as well try it and see what the buzz was about. I bought 1/2 a dozen and brought it to a friends house and rebaked it to try. 

My first thoughts... ew I did not like it at all. I am just not a fan of cheese in a tart I'm guessing because my other friends semi liked it. I dont think it was worth the wait in line, its def a HYPE, and if you looking to add more foodie photos by all means go for it. I also think it was not worth my $20 something dollars for 1/2  a dozen of those tarts. I am a bit disappointed an its overrated. I have to say the cashiers were really nice, and helpful, but I def will not be coming back to this stand to stand in line for some cheese tarts.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Get ready for a lot of 3s in the next sentence. I came here today at 3:30pm and waited for about 30 minutes, which was good, because I don't think it's worth a 3 hour wait. 

The cheese tart itself tastes like 10 ritz cheese crackers in your mouth with each bite, so don't expect this to taste like the typical Chinese egg tart. You'll either love this place or think it's mediocre.
author: Megan C.

description:
This counter is located in the basement of the SF Westfield Mall in their food court between Cako and Sur La Table, next to the Powell St BART entrance. Only food court seating available. Limit of 12 original tarts and 6 seasonal.

Seasonal Flavor: Chocolate Cheese (a collaboration with Dandelion Chocolate)

1 tart: $3.50
6 tarts: $21
Brazilian Coffee: $3.50

I came on their second day of opening May 5th, 2018. Even though they have shops in other countries, this is their first US location. Got to the location 30min before they opened and ended up waiting a little over 2.5hours (still ended up getting a tote). What made the line SUPER slow was that they only had ONE cashier (which makes absolutely NO sense). They also didn't try pre-packing boxes to speed along the line. I guess they wanted all the tarts displayed nicely on the trays.

The tarts are not too sweet and the cheese not too overpowering (even though there are 3 types of cheeses) in the tart. The crust is cookie-like and not the flaky buttery kind. While the tarts are good (the chocolate even better), they are no Pablo and not worth THAT long of a wait.
author: Kitty K.

description:
While I'm not a fan of this store being much more expensive than their other locations, the tarts I would say are worth trying at least once (but maybe after the hype wears off).  

I am hoping they add more flavors too over time.  Most of the time it seems they will only have the original flavor and sometimes chocolate unless they run out.  Tarts here cost $3.50 where in Japan, the website lists that they cost about 216 Yen (~$2).  So you're definitely paying a lot more here.  

But the tarts are unique and not like Chinese Egg Tarts for instance.  The filling is so soft, like a meringue.  Definitely, recommend eating it fresh, but that's not to say you can't.  They hold up quite well refrigerated or frozen as their website recommends.  It becomes more cheesecake-like when served chilled.  

This place is worth a try if you haven't had something like it.  The tarts are slightly savory, but still more a sweet dessert.  They're not overly sweet or rich which is great, but I could eat a whole box of these if I were hungry.  The location is also super convenient so grab one if you ever pass by (assuming the line isn't too bad).
author: Bryson L.

description:
Horrible, unprofessional customer service and rude staff! 

The line was short so I decided to give them a try. As I was approaching the line, I notice that the original cheese tarts were out. When it was finally turn, there were some that came out of the oven. The woman at the cashier said she couldn't not serve me the cheese tarts because they are too hot. Fine. I'll wait. A couple minutes past and a group of employees from the back come out and start yelling "y'all need to get at the back of the line and not block the front". What's the point in falling back in line when everyone else wants the cheese tarts??? 

People in line were asking questions and the two working the cashiers were acting real snarky. They gave brief, rude responses. 

There should be someone out front of the line directing traffic and letting people know of the wait. This places need an upgrade on customer service.
author: Marie N.

description:
My friend said I had to try the cheese tarts here so I decided to try it. My brother and I came here to try it out. The line stretched around the corner, but we waited only 15 minutes. 

We got to look inside the glass window and see the cheese tarts pop out, all hot and fresh. The boxes also had a cool design so we appreciate the boxing. 

The cheese tart themselves were nice and warm. It reminds me of a chinese egg tart (Dan tat) but with cheese instead. It tasted like sweet cream cheese in a tart.
author: Nathan C.

description: Tried the matcha honey tart today. It was okay, wasn't delicious enough to make me want to come back again. It's pricey for its size, as people have mentioned. Didn't find the tart nearly as delicious as the cheese tarts I've had in Japan. Overall, somewhat of a miss for me with the high price per tart.
author: Michelle E.

description:
The line was about 10 mins for me so it wasn't that bad. I got in line at 11:30am on a Tuesday. 

Cost: 3.5 for original, 3.65 for seasonal (chocolate made from Dandelion Chocolates). Note: 12 tarts max for original and 6 max for seasonal, per person.

Overall: I didn't know what to expect. I like cheesecake so, it's not a surprise that I like these cheese tarts. It's like a warm cheesecake (more cheese-y) on a cookie/biscuit. I'm also not a big chocolate person either but the chocolate tarts are quite tasty. Hoping for a matcha flavor next! 

Are they worth the price? Yes. Are they worth the wait in line? Nope. Just wait until the hype dies down to get them or go during an off-peak time.
author: William V.

description:
It's located down at the Westfield food court close to the Bart entrance. 
I came in on a Friday around 3pm and the wait was about 20 minutes, which wasn't as bad as I expected. By then, they did sell out of the chocolate tart so i opted in for half a dozen.
