Presentation is EVERYTHING to me lol so i was very intrigued with the box that the tarts are given in. The bottom tarts have a tab you can pull which makes the tarts easily accessible.

The tarts themselves were good. Tasted kinda like cheesecake to me. I saw them take a fresh batch out of the oven and tried to ask for them but they said no:(. They come room temperature and with a guide on how to enjoy them at different temperatures once you're home. My favorite way to eat them was baked for a few minutes in the oven. The cheese part becomes warm and gooey and the crust gets re-crisped.

 It's definitely worth a try, but don't think it's worth the wait to try again.
author: Mary R.

description:
Everything is better in japan. I had this specific bake cheese tart with my previous visits to japan and they were terrific!  A. Not disappointed that they don't also have the famous Hokkaido milk soft serve here like they do in japan. That would be awesome!

My bf and I came here because we love these tarts! Came on a Saturday and we were surprised by how short the line was. We ordered 4 cheese tarts, the crust is still crisp and buttery but the filling was a bit mushy compared to before. I did hear that these tarts are previously frozen then baked. So that might be the cause of the mushy filling. From what I remember the filling is usually stiffer and not mushy. 
 
Overall, this is decent. It should hold us over for cheese tart cravings until we can head back to japan to have more! 

Total for 4: $14
author: Stella J.

description:
Decided to brave the line today.  Waited 30 minutes on a Wednesday afternoon.  I wanted to see if these cheese tarts were really authentic. 

YES!  Do yourself a favor and try one... Or 6;). I have been to the original Bake in Japan and the flavor and texture is 100% the same!
author: Ahmed H.

description:
SERVICE (2/5): 30 min wait on Tuesday afternoon with a line that just wrapped around the corner just past the window. Service is very slow, premade tarts at the register, but takes over a minute (1 min 15 secs) for a 6 order transaction. Workers doesn't seem motivated to work here from first impressions.

TASTE (4/5): Great taste, creamy and smooth with a cookie like crust. These are served at room temp. Can't go wrong with either original and chocolate, the sweetness level is also really good, not too sweet.

ALTERNATIVE: Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts (Chinatown).
GGB is not as expensive and their egg tarts come out warm. More eggy than cheesy of course, so not as creamy. Their service is faster, but you'll wait longer for these since turnover is slow and people buy large boxes.

Conclusion: worth a try, but can wait when the line is shorter.
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Arrived about 10:20 am on a Tuesday and the line had about 20 people but we had our order 15 minutes later.

Servers were super nice and hardworking

We loved the Original more than the chocolate. 

Also, the pricing doesn't exactly match what they post as the chocolate ones rang up as $3.65 each 

I definitely will be back. Very good dessert
author: Foodlover B.

description: Legit place for your delicious cheese tarts. Cash only. Randomly open. Catch it while you can.
author: Liam P.

description:
I saw some tourists at Uniqlo with a bag of tarts from here. I had some time so decided to try it!

The line took about 45 min. They had a limit of 6 chocolates and 12 normal tarts, but they were out of chocolate. Strawberry is the next flavor which starts in June.

I have had cheese tarts from Pablo and Rikuro in Japan before, and I don't believe there was much difference in the experience. 

That said, I feel operational efficiency can witness a lot of improvement. I believe it might improve as the staff (many of whom just started) get more experienced. There's literally two (more often one since chocolate is sold out so quickly) products so these tarts should already be pre-packaged in boxes and ready to go. Customers literally wait for an employee to set up the box and carefully put 6 tarts in each.

These tarts are quite expensive, and a dozen cost me $45.57. There's a few ways to enjoy them: hot, chilled, frozen. Remember to eat within a day!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I am just not impressed nor really moved by these little cheesecakes. 

Seriously, my girl and all her friends RAVES about these things and buys them any chance she gets. I'm sure as I write this there are hidden tarts all over my house.

Maybe it's the marketing, maybe it's the weird exclusivity of how it feels when you get them because they are stupid expensive and their stores seem like feeding lines for soylent green or something. 

I have no idea, but I've had better pastries at literally every patisserie in town. 

Oh they have matcha? Whoopdy freakin' do. 

All hype, this one.
author: John W.

description:
I don't get all the complaining comparing these to egg tarts . And that it's not worth the long wait when you can go to Chinatown. Scratching head. Lol First off, these are not egg tarts. These are  Hokkaido cheese tarts that are shipped from Japan.  This is a chain located throughout Asia. I do get that it may be a preference that some may not like the runny consistency if you get it still warm, compared to when they are at room temp  they become more like a cheesecake consistency. 

Stopped by after work today 5/15 at 4:15p. Easy 15 minute wait. The line was half way from the glass corner of the store to the Bart entrance. Moved pretty quickly. Greeted with friendly staff when I got to the cashier. If you don't want the 30 to an hour wait, then don't come during peak times. Pretty simple. 

I ordered 6 of the original. Per the sales rep they usually sell out of the chocolate flavor around 2 or 3p. If you don't intend to eat them the same day, they last up to 4 days in the refrigerator as I was told. $3.50 a pop is expensive. Asked my cousin in the Philippines how much these are there, less than 2 bucks. In Japan these are 216 yen. So were overpaying about a buck fifty. Happy to have it even if overpriced. At least we have the option to get them, and not have to wait til my next trip to Asia! 

Waited til I got home to nuke it a few seconds. Cheesy melty delicious. Tastes like cheese in a tart just as the name suggests lol. If cheese is not your thing, then you may not like these. The tart is great too. Like shortbread. 

 On another note, though this may be the first chain store to arrive in the US, its actually not the first carrier.  85 degree bakery has Hokkaido Cheese Tarts that are worth a try too without the wait!
author: Erica M.

description: Melting cheese. Sweet and savoury. Freshly baked. CAN IT BE ANY BETTER THAN THIS? OMG I have such a soft spot for cheese tart and this place is LEGIT. I FELL IN LOVE. Before they opened a store in SF my aunt used to bring them all the way from Japan and keep them in the freezer. They were still very delicious but not as delicious as freshly baked ones with melting cheese inside. They should def branch out to SoCal cuz it would be a great hit. It was oh. so. fine. Watch out for the line cuz sometimes the wait can be up to 1 hr for special cheese tarts like strawberry or matcha but believe me when I say it's so worth it.
author: Nha Vy N.

description:
SOOOOOOO GOOOOOOOD!!! I've been craving these cheese tarts ever since I first tried them in Japan. I'm so happy that the Bay Area has been blessed with BAKE! It's pricier here, but so worth it. I came around 6:30 PM on grand opening day and waited almost 45 minutes. 

1 for $3.50
6 for $21
author: Robinne D.

description:
I typically don't factor in long wait times into my reviews because it's not fair to a business to judge them on how many other people arrive. That is, unless they're handling it poorly. I get that they're just starting and all the workers look like young trainees, but when the wait time could be significantly reduced, that makes me mad.

There is a single cashier and a person with the cashier who boxes the tarts. They are actually going to be dinged for being too nice because the guy was not only slow to box, he would turn the box of 6 tarts to present it to the customer for some photo opp (man get ready to get pics taken of yoyou by people in and out of line). The workers are really accommodating, but it's not necessary if there's a ton more people relying on speedy service. And only one cashier??

The cheese tarts were ok. $3.50 a pop? Eh. I say try it once and then you're good. They're a little more on the creamier, cheesy side than cheesecake. Try it out, but don't feel bad if you choose to skip waiting in line. I'm sure it'll die down within some weeks.
author: Lilian K.

description:
I've been lucky enough to have been able to try these goodies twice without having to wait in line and both were amazing! I got to try the regular cheese tart and the chocolate. The first bite into the regular tastes like a mini/air-y cheesecake, but it kind of loses the initial cheese-y taste a few bites in. As for the chocolate, it tasted like a hot chocolate in cake form. 

I don't think I'd be willing to wait in that line, but overall pretty tasty treats!
author: Carrie L.

description:
Only complaint is priciness. I enjoyed the tart, but for the price point it just doesn't seem worth it. If it was $1.50 cheaper per unit I would consider this a good deal. 

That being said, this $3.50 (at the time of this post) tart will suffice in quenching your tarty craving. It's expensive but delicious. Also be prepared to wait in line, as it gets quite a bit of traffic. Pop it in the oven for a hot minute just to get it nice and warm if you plan to eat it at home.
author: David Y.

description: The cheese tarts in this place are definitely unique and different from other places. I had gone hoping I would be able to try the matcha one and the original one, but the matcha one sold out earlier on. Sadly, it didn't seem like they would be making more during the day. The original one tasted great, it was fluffy and light. Definitely worth trying at least once. It was on the pricer side though, at around $3.50 each. And the lines tend to be long. But, give it a try!
author: I K.

description: It was a freaking miracle. I think it was like some weekday, most likely Friday around 1 or 2 PM when I was at the mall and saw that Bake for once, DID NOT have a line that stretched all the way down to the Bart area. I was like wow, guess I better buy a tart or two. Cuz you know it's never gonna get like this again. So I bought two. $3.50 for 1!! OMG!!! I bought two because I'm not gonna buy a lot just to try. When it's warm, it's good. The crust is a bit harder than I'd like. Much smaller than I thought it would be. Cheese center super creamy and sweet. I've had the Pablo's Cheese Tarts (that I kind of feel has the same concept) and that was much bigger with a softer shell for like $3? It's okay. Has way too much hype.
author: Michelle R.

description: I like baked cheese tarts!! They are so fluffy and tasty! I don't know if they are worth waiting in that massive line for (we were at the entrance of the Bart and it took us 20 minutes to get to the front... like why? They only offer so limited options and just have to put it in the box/bag.) However, it is tasty and I would recommend it if there was not like a massive line. It's also pricy.. $3.50 for a tart!
author: Jocelyn K.

description: I've had cheese tarts before, but getting freshly made ones is another story. This just blew my expectations: the crust is this thick, crunchy texture, but as soon as you bite into it, the cheese flows out. It feels like what a lava cake looks like in your mouth. Needless to say, these are very rich and filling. The matcha green tea ones are a bit less sweet than the original, so definitely try that and mix it up.
author: Jenny W.

description: Delicious cheese tart. Love my new treat. Awesome and yummy. Must try . It's worth the wait. I will be back again.
author: Juan V.

description: It's delicious but not worth the long line or nearly $4 (after tax) price tag. You can get the same things at normal bakeries.
author: John L.

description:
$3.50 for three bites of cheese tart. $1.17 per bite. Would you pay $1.17 for a bite of this? (This does NOT include the minimum 30 minute wait in line). 

I hate hype. This place isn't necessarily hyped up, but taking consideration of the price and wait, I can see the negative reviews it causes. 

If I can compare this to Zanzie's Cheesecake, I would say it's almost equivalent with Bake Cheese Tart being a bit more dense in flavor and texture. So for my final verdict? You bet I'd pay for these tiny suckers again. I'm just gonna think of it as my little reward.
author: Fiona L.

description: I would've given this place an extra star if they can be more efficient. The line wasn't too long when we came and seeing that they have the tarts ready, I thought it would be fast. But I was wrong. As everyone mentioned, they boxed the tarts as people order them and that is taking forever. We ended up waiting for about 30 mins. The tart is $3.50 each, $21 for a box of 6. We tried to eat 2 of them right away but unfortunately it's not warm. The ones we took home and heated up taste so much better. It's not too sweet and love the crunchy shell with the soft fluffy cheese sponge. I'll be back once the hype dies down and hopefully try out the chocolate version!
author: Prisilia P.

description:
Don't see how it can worth this price! $3.65?!!! Are you kidding? I came and did not have to wait at all on a Weds afternoon, after however 15 minutes looking for a parking! 
Dessert in the states is really just so overpriced!
author: Suzy V.

description:
This place is overhyped. The wait is long because there is only one cashier and one boxer fulfilling customer orders. They can literally only serve one customer at a time. 

I get there early and only wait about 30 mins, making me feel like a winner. Only to get to the front and learn they limit the quantity each customer can order. This boggles my mind. I should be able to order however much I want. It only helps their business. I was planning to get a couple dozen to share with my coworkers, which would have only spread word of their opening. But I could only order a dozen originals at a time, which meant that I couldn't share with my coworkers since a dozen was enough for my family alone.

There is no signage about their flavors - original cheese tart and chocolate cheese tart - or about the order limit. These should be disclosed in large so everyone can see it. Instead, everyone had to ask these questions when it was their time to order, making the wait time even longer. 

Fast forward, I'm back in my office and the whole trip took about an hour. I taste the tarts and they were only okay. A blander and tinier version of cheesecake.
author: S. S.

description:
Being the first U.S. store opened in SF, you can totally expect long lines.  I was lucky to get a free tart without waiting in line.  

Having had Bake when I was in Hokkaido, the U.S. version was slightly disappointing.  You can see from my photo that the top of the tart was barely baked, giving a very bland appearance to the tart.  From some of the yelp photos, you can see the tarts were unevenly baked indicating there might be hot spots in the oven? The cheese tart tasted just about the same as the ones in Japan with the exception of the high price and unappealing look.

Is it worth waiting an hour in line? I'd say no but if you have the crave, it's best to go before it's open as I was told there's no line just before the shop opens at 10am.
author: Shirley H.

description: This place has great pastries and decent coffee. Good soups, and salads for lunch. I go here every day and buy stuff. They want a long review so let me tell you what I really think.... I've never actually been here but I'm sure it's very nice.
author: Thomas A.

description: My husband and I noticed this place a while back but we wanted to save our tummies for another dessert. Haha. We happened onto this place around 10am on a Friday and there was no line. We just ate breakfast at a pastry shop 90 minutes earlier so we ordered one to share for ~4 dollars which is pretty hefty for just one. We liked that it was a combination of salty and sweet kinda of like salted cheese. We enjoyed it. Like someone else mentioned, it wasn't too warm when we ordered it. Overall, it is good. I will prob take friends who are visiting to check this place out but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Came in around 10am, omg, when the mall entry door opened, there was already a huge line formed!!!(not sure how people can get into the mall before 10am) waited for 38 min getting that! When the line moved, finally I understand how this place formed. Actually all of the cheese tarts are previously frozen! And they just added egg wash, then put into the oven! I thought all of the cheese tart are freshly made!
Price wise, 3.5 for original flavor, 3.65 for chocolate flavor + tax! I will never wait for 30 min to buy the previously frozen cheese tart again! Will come back once the line the shorter

--update on 5/31/18
Line moves faster in the afternoon, it took me about 10min to get to buy the tarts. The reason I am giving them 3 stars is I observed that the people might get extra one free cheese tart if you buy 6 depend on how the packaging person like you or not. The lady in front me gets a free one, but I did not even I bought a dozen... please do not do that so obvious. It makes me feel bad!
author: Nina H.

description: Extremely overpriced for basically just a cheese cake! The green one even doesn't taste good at all! So don't get fooled by seeing the long line, I guess people are curious like us.
author: Arin G.

description:
Expensive. Not something I would buy often. Size is very mall, I would finish it in two bite. 
If price is cheaper or size bigger, I don't mind eating it everyday in the morning with coffee or tea.

They have their seasonal flavor limited quantity in the morning, and limited quantity in the afternoon. (They didn't do a good job on advising this). I went around 11:30am, and they told me seasonal flavor sold out, next badge needs to wait after 12. (Ugh....)

Pre order needs to be made 7 day in advance, for at least 34 or 36 pieces.
author: X G.

description:
The cheese tart were really yummy. Five star for the cheese tart!

I waited an hour in line yesterday for these. Not worth the hour wait (I love dessert but I hate waiting), but honestly I don't mind getting it once the line isn't so bad.

I had one at room temperature and one after it's been fridged. Different texture, but after it's fridged it tastes like cheesecake more and I quite love it.
author: Angel P.

description:
Taste like a soft cheesecake with a harder crust. I'm not a fan of cheesecake so that's probably why I don't really this. 

The work flow is very inefficient when I went and that's probably why the line was moving so slow. I kid you not when I say they take 5 seconds to open a bag and 2 people to put the box in a bag. Why they need 2 people? No idea. This is simply a one person job. The 2nd person should've been on her way boxing the second order, but nope she's assisting with the bagging. Maybe this place is still working out its kinks since they just opened.
author: Michelle T.

description:
It's sad to say that whilst the cheese tarts are good, the customer service for me F'ed up! 

Today was the first day of the strawberry cheese tarts. We got here a little after 2 pm.  And one of the employees came out and said they're 2 o'clock batch of strawberry cheese tarts are selling out and the next batch would be at 3. Ok that fine we'll wait. When we got up the the front it was a little after 2:30. We asked if we can just pay for the strawberry one and just wait on the side. The same chick said we couldn't pay first. And then she said it's a first come first serve. That got me F'ed up! Nah I'm here now and you have them so serve me. If not I'll wait here till 3. 

I just didn't understand their logic on selling the limited edition flavors. They need a better system for their lines and a new crew cuz they were GARBAGE! 

Still got my strawberry cheese tarts tho!
author: Marilyn P.

description: Have to say this is the most popular​  bake store recently​ in San​ Francisco, comes from Japan, and now, open not enough a month, but every day​ will see a long line waiting in front of the store. Especially​ weekend, at least up to 45mins waiting. Speak as the tasty, I think if it is a regular​ store no need to wait a ​long time, I will say it worth a try, but plus have to wait so long, I don't think it worth ...
author: Faye L.

description: It's basically a soft cheesecake in a buttery tart shell - but what's not to love about that? If you prefer a denser cheesecake, refrigerate the tart for an hour! Still tastes great the next day - be sure to pick up half a dozen because lines are long!
author: Weich Y.

description:
The cheese tart is yummy! I only had the original flavor since they ran out of chocolate. I had mine stored at room temperature for a few hours before eating.  The texture was light, fluffy, creamy, and not overwhelmingly sweet.

About the wait though... it's pretty bad. I started in line about 8ft out the mall entrance and it took 50 min. It's not the length of the line that's bad, the most frustrating part is that it moves slow. I'm told that they purposely do this to have their limited supply last the entire day, which is understandable.

I'm not going to count the line against my rating though. I expect it to die down, and hopefully at that point I can enjoy some really nice cheese tarts without a dreadful wait.
author: Posu Y.

description: If you want to taste how heavenly a tart could taste, this is the place to be. Honestly, it is the best dessert you'll have in SF - better than Ghirardelli which is too sweet for my taste. They sometimes have long queues though, so I would recommend going here in non peak hours.
author: Sonal B.

description:
Yeah, the cheese tarts are good but the service is horrible. We got in line and saw they had seasonal strawberries ones not in the oven yet. So we order the cheese tarts and monitored when the strawberry tarts were put in the oven. Got in line again to catch the strawberry ones coming out of the oven so we can order it since its first come first serve. 

It was only one small tray and each person can buy a max of 6. So we asked to order the strawberry tarts since we see them... right there... on the counter... all baked and cheesy like their suppose to be. She said they have to cool down. We asked if we can pay for them first, she said no. So we ask how long do they have to cool down for? She said 15 minutes. So we asked should we just wait in line again and when we get to the front it'll should cooled? She said yes. So we got to the end of the line and then literally not even one minute later she puts out the tray and the guy who was behind us got to order 6. 

So we're pissed cause now it will all be gone by the time we get back up to the front. We went up to ask what that was all about. The next customer in line even knew we were waiting and said you guys can cut me since I know you were waiting and the manager there said well we still won't sell it to you. Ridiculous. Either they just did it on purpose or they literally cannot remember they told a customer it will take 15 minutes to cool down and then put the tray out right after. They kept saying that's their policy and that's it. They need to make common sense apart of their policy.
author: Thao V.

description:
I enjoyed japanese cheese tarts at another place in SF so I wanted to give Bake a try.
 Its located next to the metro entrance at the mall next to the food court, right next to Cako stand. 
This was the 2nd day of opening, and I maybe waited in line for 40 min? I arrived around 4 and the limited chocolate cheese tarts were sold out already. 

So what about the tarts? It was pretty good! When I ate one instantly to try, it was warm & gooey. But definitely preferred it cold & refrigerated. Crust was lightly sweet & crispy. 

I knocked off 1 star for efficiency. But its a new place so they're probably working out the kinks. I would go back maybe when the hype dies down a little more.
author: Kathleen A.

description:
Yay for hype! I happened to be passing through the Westfield Mall and had a little bit of time to burn. A friend mentioned this hot new "cheese tart" place last week and so I joined the queue and salivated at row after row of warm tarts.

Feeling generous, I bought one for each of my housemates, as well as one for me. This was more expensive than imagined - there's a slight ($1) discount if you buy 6. I bought 5 and spent $19, although thankfully they came in a box that made it less terrifying to immediately to jump on BART. Overall, I think i waited about 15 minutes, not awful, but not great either.

I waited until I got off BART before gingerly opening the box. The tarts hadn't been crushed, which was a relief. I sat and admired the $3.80 tart for a minute and then took a bite. It was delicious - the "cheese" is actually more like custard and the crust was baked to crunchy perfection. I took another delicious bite. One more and the tart was gone.

Summary: tasty tart but most definitely overpriced. I'd feel slightly better if it was close to $3 or about 25% larger. At $3.80 though, this was more expensive than I habitually spend on baked goods, particularly those with a long wait. While the price isn't quite in cronut territory, it's considerably less filling than a cronut.
author: Sunil S.

description: I spend the day in Westfield with my friends and we saw the fresh make cheese tarts. I was never try it before and I purchased 6 of them for $23 dollars. After I try them it was not as good as I thought and also very pricey. Won't be back again.
author: Tam K.

description:
Nah!!!

It is just a cheese tart. They try too hard to make it exclusive. Does not worth your time to wait in line and when you get to the cashier they tell you that you cannot get the flavor you want when it is almost ready and tell u to get back in line if you want one. Won't allow you buy and wait around. Don't like this kind of business model. My body does not need your tart to survive.  Save your time to be in line to do some fun thing.
author: Ting O.

description:
I hope the owner read this review.. Holy crap i just got off the line with the most rude employee ever work in this place.

The tart is awesome, seriously.. This rating is for employing a rude employee with fake smile and straight up say "NO" to your face with a super fake ass smile.. She's not even that cute to begin with.. Holy crap and she work in food industry where customer service exist.. With no apology, sorry we can't sell those until it's ready, and straight "NO" like it's get store.. We're not in the army girl, and you're just a worker..

So ever the owner is, read this and hire employee that has manner not attitude.. I just found our her name is ESTHER... Get her training in customer service..
author: Junius S.

description: Ive had these for the first time when we went to thailand. When we saw it was coming to sf, we had to get them. First things first, these little things are soo good. They tastes exactly how i remembered in thailand. The outside is crispy. The filling is so creamy and runny. It literally explodes in your mouth. The cheese is not too rich and has the perfect consistency. It is best to eat it fresh out the oven. You can also store it in the fridge and save it for later. The tarts will taste more like a cheesecake though if you refrigerate it. Its way more expensive here compared to thailand. I dont know why i am so shocked. Lol definitely worth the trip out to sf.
author: Dynaton T.

description: After my third time trying it I've finally decided to post a review. Had read from other posts that they can be bought warm, so was disappointed to be told it's sold room temperature. Maybe I can bring a heating element to diy at the mall as warm tarts always beat unearned. The coffee was awful and the choices for cream was fat free watery milk and almond milk. I think they had lattes before if I'm not mistakened. Disappointed! Will have to avoid at those high prices for these tarts and get Portuguese equivalents cheaper at Chinese bakeries or settle for eggtarts. These cheese tarts are from Japan so I'll just have to eat a ton when I visit. I'm pretty sure it's sold warm if not hot there.  I guess if I wasn't so lazy I could bake my own with cream cheese after looking for a premade crust.lol
author: Ken K.

description:
I had to kill some time before I bought Century 9 opened, so a quick stroll to the food market showed (for the first time I've ever seen) zero line. 
I was the first in line, and though I'd read many reviews regarding different flavors such as strawberry & chocolate, the flavors are only seasonal.  (Matcha will be a flavor they offer later this month). Otherwise, it's just the original plain flavor. 
Although I've been to Japan many, many times, I'd never heard of this chain, so I haven't tried it. 

I had read they are best warm, and because I was the very first customer, and watched them programming the oven, I figured I'd better sit down to enjoy the creamy goodness while it was still warm. 
Unfortunately, it was only room temperature. 
I wasn't sure what to expect, so when I took my first bite, I was surprised at the texture. 
As previous reviewers have said, it's by no means a cheesecake consistency. It very much more like pudding. 
Don't get me wrong, it was good, but I'm glad I didn buy 6.  The crust was sweet, crisp, & delicious. 
I doubt I'd go back there again. Although the employees were friendly & the cake was good, it just wasn't good enough for a repeat visit.
author: Reed S.

description:
Finally got to try the hype!  It's crazy how popular this place is.  I've had cheese tarts in Japan and they were really good (soft & creamy) but the price was much more reasonable than here.  Easily can devour this in a bite or two! 
Ordered: strawberry cheese tart  ($3.65 each)
author: Mikayla M.

description:
A lot of hype about the cheese tart they had to offer.  There was a fairly long line that was not moving because the majority of the people in line were waiting for the strawberry flavored ones that were still needed to be made.  I was still willing to wait for the original ones I wanted regardless of how overpriced(6 for $21) it was.

So why one star?

An employee announced that they were willing to start a second line for customers who wanted the original cheese tarts.  As I moved to this line, another employee suddenly announced that the strawberry tarts were ready to come out and the lady decided to cut off the line starting with myself and tells us that we needed to get back to the other line where the line gained 10+ more customers thus making the line and wait longer for myself and others.

I don't understand her logic of sending us to the back of the line and I made myself clear that I would only purchase the original tarts regardless of the strawberry ones being ready that the majority of the people waited in the long for 1+ hours for.

Very disappointed and inconvenient.  I confronted this spastic employee about the situation and she did not see an issue.

Other than this inconvenience and the overpriced tarts, they are just OK and not worth the wait and the hype that gullible people eat up.  Obviously the ones in Japan and Taiwan are better.
author: Jr A.

description: I would say it's kinda worth it for about $3.50. It was pretty good and I would recommend this to other people. I tried the original one and it had a good filling. The line was long and I didn't like that part. The way that they were selling it was really slow (especially when selling only 1 item? C'mon now). Plus there was only one line/cashier and like dozens people in line. I waited for 45 minutes and barely made it to the line before they closed it. So it was not good.
author: Maria S.

description: My husband loves this place and always comes home carrying a beautifully packaged dessert for us.  The packaging as I've already mentioned is really pretty.  The tarts are a bit expensive and tastes to me like cheesecake.  I wouldn't go out of my way to eat one of these things but if I was in the area would choose it as a dessert.
author: Mariam A.

description:
My coworker brought them in and he placed them in the fridge.
I decided to microwave mine for 10 secs and it actually was quite good!
I was worried about the cheese flavor being too strong but it was really light and the crust was good.

Surpassed my expectations but would I buy for $4 a piece? EHHHH
author: Christine M.

description: HOLY @#*@#(*$*(&@#*(&#@!!!!! Don't listen to what anyone says. It's not overrated; it's worth the wait. It's very good; it's phucking delicious.  I am not a fan of cheesecake but I can certainly get down with these cheese tarts!
author: Diana M.

description:
Finally got to witness the goodness of Bake Cheese Tart at their first ever U.S location in San Fran!! 
Luckily, my cousins & I weren't met with too much of a long wait or long line when we came around 1:30pm on a Thursday. The first time I tried this amazing cheese tart was in April, from a friend who had brought them from his Philippines trip & man, one or two were not enough. 
These are not your ordinary cheese tarts. The crust is baked to perfection, perfectly crisp & the fluffy cheese filling is made of 3 different kinds of cheese from Japan. Each tart is $3.50 a piece, 6 tarts for $21.00, which in my opinion, is a bit pricey. However, I believe it's worth it!!! Their presentation is so nice too- they place the tarts in a box with separators so the tarts don't get damaged :) They also include a little card that explains the different ways you can enjoy your cheese tarts. 
My family loved them & will definitely be coming back for more. You have to give these cheese tarts a try & you won't regret it! I loved them so much, that I brought a dozen back home to NY with me (to share one with a friend of course!) Lol. On Friday, I think due to the higher demand/busier day, they did limit one person to 3 boxes. To maintain their freshness, I placed my box of cheese tarts in the freezer. I tried one straight from the freezer & they're delicious!! The texture is still crisp& the filling is like biting into a nice ice cream/cheesecake texture! 

Anyway, I can't wait until my next CA trip to come back to Bake Cheese Tart! Also, when will you guys finally share some of the cheese tart love with the East Coast- NY? :) My friends & I will be patiently waiting lol !
author: Carla L.

description:
Nothing to write home about here. Is it worth standing in line for an hour pius? NO! However, I will say I liked the regular over the chocolate. I also think it will taste better once refrigerated. Supposedly it will have the texture of cheese cake. I'll try the refrigerated aspect when the lines are down to 2-3 minutes. 

And put another POS location in.
author: Anthony W.

description: Surprising good. We had the original. The strawberry was sold out each time. We got the original and then added caramel and cinnamon. They were slightly warm and tasty. The line is a little long but it moves fast.
author: Nancy P.

description: Hokkaido Cheese Tarts that are worth waiting in line for. I would come here again even if I can't eat them all the time. There's a limit per customer, and it's a bit pricey, but it's honestly worth it. They sell for 3.50 each or 21 for a half dozen. I went the hour before they closed, and the wait in line is only about 15 minutes. 12/10 recommend if you've never tried it! It's like the ones at 85 bakery but BETTER. The strawberry tart was delicious as the original cheese tart was too.
author: Anne Marie S.

description:
I ventured to play Pokemon Go and start my journey to Powell Street in Westfield Shopping Center this year's Labor Day. I was so hungry and had to start my day eating brunch - so I first ate at Koja Kitchen ( I will give this review on another post). Then I need to eat a dessert, so there was Beard Papa's eclairs and cheesecake, and finally saw Bake Cheese Tart opened. It was like in Japan on how this bakery chain specialize their take on a Baked Cheese tart, and this is more of an acquired taste. But I was so excited it opened and willing to try what this Hokkaido Baked Cheese tart is all about. Hmmm... saw the sign - each tart cost $3.50 and if you buy 6 for $20.93. These prices don't include tax and it is better to buy a box of these to share with family and friends.
Hooo... still a short line after 12:26 PM on a Monday afternoon during Labor Day. I know right, this is probably my opportunity to taste these Japanese pastries.
I liked the packaging which is a box but it separates each tart with care. Very typical of Japanese ingenuity, care of packaging and quality of service and respect of the product has to be well- presented at all times. I am very impressed. Customer service and quality of product and service were all top-notch excellent. I bought the Original and the Matcha flavors.
The tarts are made up of a buttery cookie tart shell, and filling is salty, creamy savory cheese. So this pastry offers the best of both worlds - buttery, rich, crispy, slightly sweet butter cookie tart and the cheese filling is creamy, smooth, notes of salty, creamy cheeses. OMG... The original is really good as a snack or dessert. The ratio between the tart shell and cheese filling is right for both. Also, I tasted the Matcha flavor- the Matcha powder was way too bitter - they might have used Grade B Matcha powder not like the tea ceremony grade. So it tends to be bitter, but you get the green tea leaves taste. I didn't like the Matcha. I think the Matcha flavor is targeted for adults who are not into sweet desserts. So they offer these 2 flavors, and it is a matter of preference of taste. Bake Cheese Tarts are great for sharing to families and friends. If you want to give something special for a loved one, or maybe that special friend. Bring home a box of each flavor, and you will never regret it.
Very few Japanese bakery chains venture overseas especially in Northern California. So this product is so worth trying!
author: Jade M.

description:
After a hahaha hour wait in line, I  asked for 3 tarts for a total of about $12. Because the tarts are often runny I asked for a box. I was told that I could not have a box unless I bought another tart for  an additional 3.50 plus tax ($4). So I could have a box for approximately 16 dollars.
Please do the math .. a 12 dollar purchase isn't enough to allow for a 20 cent box! And given the frequently inconsistent texture, I could very well  have a bag of sludge by the  time I arrived home!
In Japan they sell for 1.25 to 1.50. the profit margin can certainly allow for a box.

Taste worth a wait. Product inconsistent: sometimes it is runny and other times set.  Can be a mess when runny.
author: John H.

description: I tried to come opening weekend. But they sporadically closed the line. Not sure why - maybe they thought they were going to run out or didn't want the line to get insane. But we came back about half an hour later to look at the menu and it was open. We were in a rush so we didn't want to wait again. Fast forward 3 weeks later, I came on a Friday afternoon. Wait was 35 minutes, which isn't so bad or as bad as I was expecting. I first had a cheese tart in Japan. And have tried a few places here in the US but have not found anything close. Until now.... Still not as great as what they have in Japan but pretty good and pretty close. I do wish it was warmer when I got it. They were steadily taking the tarts out of the oven the whole time you're in line. But they serve you the earlier, room temperature ones; not the ones fresh out of the oven. I had one right away and the cheese was melt in your mouth. The crust is twice baked, from what I'm told and it was crispy yet flaky.  I had one the next day after I kept it in the fridge and nuked it for like 12 seconds in the microwave. It was very good still. But prob best when eaten fresh. Worth the wait and price - not really. It's pricey for a small tart - $3.50 each and there's no discount if you buy more. I hope to have it again in the future but hope the hype dies down and I can just walk up when shopping in the mall and grab a tart as a snack.  Oh and I do need to try to get the chocolate cheese tart too.
author: Alison W.

description: I waited for the hype of this place to die down since it opened I believe earlier this spring. I used to pass by on my way to work and see a line completely out the mall that would dip into the BART station which is absolutely insane. With that said, lines are relatively short now with a min wait time of at least 5 min. You're never really waiting for the tarts to come out of the oven as they are already ready to go, but youre mostly waiting for people in line to determine how many they want! Currently there are 3 options, the traditional cheese tart, matcha and gold matcha that has been filled with black honey and garnished with a little gold flake. The regular cheese tart is delicious. Super creamy, not overly sweet and if you luck out, you may receive a super fresh one. The matcha is bleh. It's all matcha and not much else. If you are really into a strong matcha flavor then this is for you. The black matcha though is perfect mix of matcha and sweetness of honey that the plain matcha is truly lacking. Granted, these things are pretty expensive and really only for treat yourself moments. At $3.50 a piece for a relatively small dessert is pretty pricey. It's definitely a try once experience though just to fulfill the hype.
author: Kaylin-Marie D.

description: Pretty good, but if the line looks crazy long, I don't think it's something worth the wait. Luckily I only waited ~5-10 mins because I came here on a Wednesday ~2:15pm. I had no regrets about just getting one ($3.50). Maybe it'll taste better after being refrigerated? Also if this place is infamous for long lines, maybe have two registers instead of one?
author: Annie S.

description: I love this so much it really tasted good. It my favorite place here in sf. Thank you to bring it here from Japan.
author: Chia Yu L.

description: Tastes super great, like a warm and melty japanese cheesecake. Only thing is at 3.5 a pop, I would be more happy with three fresh hong kong egg tarts from SF chinatown. Would definitely buy again for like, 2.5 each.
author: Josh L.

description: This is the best cream cheese tart you will ever have, Paris included!!!  You will encounter s line, but it goes fast!!! This is their only product for sale.  They have a cute little box that holds a 6 pack, which I highly recommend.  Back to the cheese tarts, slightly warm, light and soft sweet cream cheese filling, crispy crust.  Grab a Peet's coffee or hot ocha, and have a party!!!!!  This is the only store in SF right now.  It originated in Hokkaido, Japan.
author: Gerry K.

description: I am a girl who is serious about her cheese. I wish I had a snapshot of my face when I first bit into one of these cheese tarts because I was genuinely blown away by the experience. This place is kind of pricey, and the line gets long, but the quality of the tarts is undeniable. The crust is firm and contrasts really nicely against the creaminess of the flavorful cheese filling. Would highly recommend getting one of these (but only if the line isn't too long).
author: Madeleine L.

description: Got 2 and finished it quick between me, wife, and baby. A bit too sweet for our liking so probably just try it once and never again.
author: Ben M.

description: I REAAAALLY wanted to like this place, bc the cheese cake itself is absolutely delicious! Honestly, guys, the tartlet is not too sweet or dense like 99% of the cheese cakes in America. This little guy is light, but rich enough, and quite refined. BUT $3.50 FOR A MINI TART THAT YOU CAN EAT IN ONE BITE?! REALLY? (Yes, I did eat my second tartlet in one bite just to see if I could--and I did.) I think a creampuff from Beard Papa's would be money better spent if you're on the hunt for dessert.
author: Rie U.

description: If you go midday on a weekday, there's only a small line. Once people start getting off work there's a line that wraps around the corner. The tarts are delish if you heat them up a little, but if I had waited in a long line for them I wouldn't have thought it worth it then.
author: Tiffany M.

description: 100% not worth the 40 minute wait. Bake Cheese Tart is stupidly inefficient in their business operation (maybe it's intentional -- I don't know). Instead of having people take your order in line and having employees continuously boxing tarts in the kitchen to keep the flow of customers going, it's one person, one order at a time. The single point of sale system is really an oversight and demonstrates a huge lack of knowledge on how to run a business. Would I come again? Definitely not.
author: Austin W.

description:
Pro-tip: Wait at the underground Powell Muni/BART stop 10-15 mins before opening (9:45AM-9:50AM) and you won't be in a longer line.

I tried going on opening day and there were supposedly 3 hour lines that went deep into the BART station. Gave it another shot this morning and once the mall opened at 10AM, I was the 3rd in line and waited an additional 5 minutes or so to get to the front.

Quality wise, you can tell that they put good care into the bake and the packaging, but in the end, is it worth $3.50 per tart and potentially long lines? I'd say no, not really, especially knowing that Chinatown is close by with plenty of good egg tarts.

It's definitely a thicker consistency and liken it to somewhere between a cheesecake and a Chinese egg tart. Taste wise, it's got a creamy lightly sweet taste and a solid crunch, but still not worth the crazy hype. I think if they lowered the price by $1 and have a guaranteed wait less than 5 minutes, it'd bring me back.
author: Jeff N.

description: I was disappointed upon opening considering 4 of 6 were over cooked, blackened on half of the tart ( beyond that of purpose.)  I say this because uneven color is acceptable, but not when hints of " burned" linger in your mouth.
author: Kelly F.

description: Great spot if you want a Japanese bake cheese tart, because that's all they serve here! They do have seasonal specials such as a chocolate tart or strawberry tart for summer, but their standard cheese tarts are delicious on their own. There are toppings available to the side counter - cinnamon, chocolate syrup or caramel. A tart costs $3.50 each, which feels a bit like sticker shot especially if you've had similar cheese tarts at 85C Bakery (which are better IMO). Worth trying if you have a few minutes to spare in line!
author: Edwina D.

description: I had never heard of this place before and didn't know what it was but I just  got in line because I saw a bunch of other people lining up for it. It's basically a small Japanese cheesecake. I liked it because it was less sweet and more tart than a regular cheesecake. They are pretty pricey at $3.50 for a tiny piece. Be aware that there is no seating, it's just a window at the mall where you buy your goods to go. It was good but I don't get why people would line up for this. While in line, I overheard people saying it's the only location in the US, and that they may be introducing new flavors in the future.
author: Shilpa Y.

description: Came specifically becoz of the recent hype of how good these tarts are. Waited for half an hour (not too bad, as they have tons of tarts ready to sell). I finally got a dozen of it. After taste them, my honest opinion is the tart is way too small for $3.5 and crust can be a little less sweet, then it would be perfect.  I haven't tried their chocolate tart yet. Heard you have to be there before 2 pm to get them. My question is Why can't they make more of the chocolate flavor too?
author: Elly S.

description: Finally got to try the place after a fourth attempt with fellow foodie coworkers. The line scared us away the past few times and it's been kind of a myth that we would ever get to try it. I'm always suspicious of hyped up places but I can't deny that I enjoyed every bite of that tiny little morsel. Really reminds me of Porto's in LA but with a fluffier texture. It's a really good balance of sweet yet savory. Don't recommend more than one if you are trying to work on that summer bod.
author: Jeanie L.

description:
Ordered:
Matcha Cheese Tart - Toooooo much matcha; YUCKY

Regular Cheese tart - Meh... nothing special
author: Katy N.

description: After having a late lunch at Westfield Mall and heading back to Bart, we ran across this Japanese chain 'Bake Cheese Tart' shop. Not having ever tried before, my friend treated the group to sample the original cheese tart. Wow, the crunchy cookie like crust complemented the fluffy cheese filling, delicious! The chocolate and daily special strawberry tarts were already sold out :(.  Pricy, unique treat, worth trying.
author: Jason T.

description: Hello to every one out here, am here to share the unexpected miracle that happened to me six days ago, my name is shrom nath i live in Dermark, and I`m happily married to a lovely and caring wife,with three kids a very big problem occurred in my family eight months ago,between me and my wife so terrible that she took the case to court for a divorce she said that she never wanted to stay with me again,and that she did not love me anymore So she packed out of my house and made me and my children passed through severe pains. I tried all my possible means to get her back,after much begging,but all to no avail and she confirmed it that she has made her decision,and she never wanted to see me again. So on one evening,as i was coming back from work,i met an old friend of mine who asked of my wife So i explained every thing to her,so she told me that the only way i can get my wife back,is to visit a spell caster,because it has really worked for her too So i never believed in spell,but i had no other choice,than to follow her advice.
